content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Horrible, unbalanced, irredeemably broken, counter-intuitive game design that doesn't work. Yes it's "unique," but so is a bicycle with cubes instead of wheels. Does that mean it works as a game? No it does not, contrary to what the♥♥♥♥♥♥eating lowlifes at charlatan blogs like RPS might tell you.I was initially drawn to this game because of its intriguing promise of a tower defense dungeon crawler. "How the heck would that work?" I asked myself. DoTE's answer was: "lol it doesn't, but thanks for the money." What we have here, ladies and gentlemen, is your classic Emperor's New Clothes situation. 90% positive reviews, naturally, because none of the brain surgeons writing reviews for this abomination wants to be the first to ask why the Emperor's strolling around in the nude. The RPS monkey ♥♥♥♥ers gave it a rave review based on ten minutes of cretinous button mashing at a trade show so it can't be bad! If your first instinct is to dismiss this as a cracked design due to its many fatal flaws immediately apparent to even the most casual connoisseur of game design, allow me to say you would be perfectly right in saying so.What's wrong with it, you may ask? Where do I begin? It's a mix of real time and turn based which may strike you as totally counter-intuitive at first. Oh, and you can pause. So... why is there an RTS component again? Presumably the developers didn't have the imagination to create a turn-based TD game and instead forced RTS onto it because of the conventional wisdom that all TD MUST be in real time. Just like all shooters must be in first person, herp derp. But I'm getting away from the point. This isn't necessarily a fatal flaw in the design, even if it is incredibly clumsy. The fatal flaw is introduced in the interaction between the game's janky real time combat and the permadeath system. As you might expect from a game advertising itself as a "roguelike dungeon crawl" this game has permadeath, which is fine. The problem is in how easily your characters (in whom you're compelled to sink huge amounts of resources. Did I not talk about that? There's no XP. Of course there isn't! Instead you have to spend the Food resource to level your characters. Because every game has to have that FIDS resource system crammed into its design.) die with ZERO warning. You can look away for a split second to build some towers or some♥♥♥♥♥♥and one of your characters will be dead when you focus on them again. Great game design. They aren't incapacitated or require reviving or anything, they are immediately DEAD when their hp goes down to 0, effectively ending your run. Contrast with the clever character permadeath system from something like Darkest Dungeon.I could go on with other similarly horrid examples, but I'll spare you. Broken, non-functional, non-viable, vomit-inducing game that should've been aborted in the prototype stage, but instead astonishingly made it to release. I keep trying to find some good in it but come up empty handed at each attempt. And finally, the lazy hipster pixel graphics as the icing on this particular♥♥♥♥♥♥cake. Last time I give this studio any money, and I've already given them plenty.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rogue Like Dungeon crawler.You end up on this planet after "your" (aka the ship you were on as staff or prisoner) prison ship got attacked and destroyed. Dont worry you managed to launch a escape pod and escape death... for now.Your only option once landed with 2 survivors is to open the door out the unknown... with a minor hope of a ticket somewhere away from this dangerous place.Economy is split between Four things.Food to level and heal your heroes.Science to remove cooldown on abilites or research new modules that will make your journey easier (to make it possible that you might survive without good luck or being veteran to the game)building material (dont recall correct term) That you build modules that increases one of these three or many minor one with offensive defensive or boosts to the room you build them in.And finally we have Dust... Your best friend. Without this materia darkness will consume the entire level. Also the merchants love Dust since it is also the currency in this game. So will you spend some dust to buy a new weapon or armor? Or will you light another room so unknown lurkers cant spawn there to attack you that might occur when you open up yet another door into the unknown? The option is yours, but know this; To many dark rooms will for certain mean a bigger fight once they come... And they will come for either your blood or powercrystal (your dungeonheart where dust is stored).There is currently a bunch of diffrent unique heroes(more being added all the time), you start with a few ones, all being unique. But during your journey you will run into outsiders, good and twisted characters, all ready to join you up to a party of max 4. Keep them alive for 3 levels and your permantly unlock them for your next round... which open up the game depth even more. The levels is randomized, however the number of doors isnt. (currently)This game currently in beta, the devs got a very clear structure of what they want to do and they have frequently updates for the game.  You shouldnt be to worried about this game not being finished or ending up as a mess.Currently the game is fun enough and with more content being added it refreshes the replay value of the game.I highly doubt you gonna regret getting this game. But if your in doubt, do more research or wait until complete.Personally I recommend this game.

content:

Early Access Review

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Horrible, unbalanced, irredeemably broken, counter-intuitive game design that doesn't work. Yes it's "unique," but so is a bicycle with cubes instead of wheels. Does that mean it works as a game? No it does not, contrary to what the♥♥♥♥♥♥eating lowlifes at charlatan blogs like RPS might tell you.I was initially drawn to this game because of its intriguing promise of a tower defense dungeon crawler. "How the heck would that work?" I asked myself. DoTE's answer was: "lol it doesn't, but thanks for the money." What we have here, ladies and gentlemen, is your classic Emperor's New Clothes situation. 90% positive reviews, naturally, because none of the brain surgeons writing reviews for this abomination wants to be the first to ask why the Emperor's strolling around in the nude. The RPS monkey ♥♥♥♥ers gave it a rave review based on ten minutes of cretinous button mashing at a trade show so it can't be bad! If your first instinct is to dismiss this as a cracked design due to its many fatal flaws immediately apparent to even the most casual connoisseur of game design, allow me to say you would be perfectly right in saying so.What's wrong with it, you may ask? Where do I begin? It's a mix of real time and turn based which may strike you as totally counter-intuitive at first. Oh, and you can pause. So... why is there an RTS component again? Presumably the developers didn't have the imagination to create a turn-based TD game and instead forced RTS onto it because of the conventional wisdom that all TD MUST be in real time. Just like all shooters must be in first person, herp derp. But I'm getting away from the point. This isn't necessarily a fatal flaw in the design, even if it is incredibly clumsy. The fatal flaw is introduced in the interaction between the game's janky real time combat and the permadeath system. As you might expect from a game advertising itself as a "roguelike dungeon crawl" this game has permadeath, which is fine. The problem is in how easily your characters (in whom you're compelled to sink huge amounts of resources. Did I not talk about that? There's no XP. Of course there isn't! Instead you have to spend the Food resource to level your characters. Because every game has to have that FIDS resource system crammed into its design.) die with ZERO warning. You can look away for a split second to build some towers or some♥♥♥♥♥♥and one of your characters will be dead when you focus on them again. Great game design. They aren't incapacitated or require reviving or anything, they are immediately DEAD when their hp goes down to 0, effectively ending your run. Contrast with the clever character permadeath system from something like Darkest Dungeon.I could go on with other similarly horrid examples, but I'll spare you. Broken, non-functional, non-viable, vomit-inducing game that should've been aborted in the prototype stage, but instead astonishingly made it to release. I keep trying to find some good in it but come up empty handed at each attempt. And finally, the lazy hipster pixel graphics as the icing on this particular♥♥♥♥♥♥cake. Last time I give this studio any money, and I've already given them plenty.

												Dungeon of the Endless is a really kickass RPG/rogue-like Dungeon-Defense game. It's very fun with multiple people but there are a few issues, you see, to unlock a character (even in multiplayer) you have to hold that character in your control for 3 floors after finding them, but only you unlock them. The only other issue I've had is that every time we get to around Floor 10-12 the game auto-crashes or will freeze, or the elevator simply wont trigger, so at this current point it is unwinnable for me or my friends. Maybe we're the only ones with this issue, but i've come to doubt that. Other than the previous listed issues, Dungeon of the Endless, like its' other games, kicks total♥♥♥♥♥ fun gameplay, cool items (and item descriptions) cool characters with great backstories, good OST, and most of all, Endless Fun.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												Amazing game. Simple concept, defend yourself and your resources while trying to advance through oncoming waves of enemies. Dungeon of The Endless is a great mix of turn based strategy with tower defense mechanics. It's an oddly addicting game that will have you saying, "just one more floor", again and again. This is especially fun if you have played a bit of Endless Legend as the lore carries between the two. Unlocking heroes and new ships is very addicting and well worth the price. Multiplayer is great and probably the highpoint of this gem; getting a great team of heroes is the most amazing feeling. I can highly recommend another title from the masterminds at Amplitude, they have gotten it right yet again.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												So remember those other two games that this dev studio made that were super innovative that I like a lot?This is like those games and not like those games. It's like them in that it's super innovative. It's not like them in almost (I say again almost) every other respect.This is kind of a dungeon crawl. And kind of a tower defense. It has elements of turn based and real time strategy involved. It's kind of funny but can be kind of tense and serious. It has a perfectly winning single player and a perfectly winning multiplayer that are virtually identical and don't suffer at all from this. Every choice might matter and it might not matter at all when the next door opens. You can probably play through a few sessions in ten minutes and have a perfectly good time or agonize over a campaign for hours, even yelling at friends in VOIP the whole time. You kind of want to screw around with this game and you kind of want to take it seriously and beat it, because it is quite simply very difficult and simultaneously very fun.For Amplitude: I am sold. Really, just keep up quality like this and I will tell you to shut up and take my money every time. You guys are amazing and I really hope everything goes well for you for this and any other project you guys work on.TL,DR- Buy this, play it, have fun, there is literally no reason not to.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								WHat is there to say about DotE?Its good.! Its a Roguelike, its a Tower Defense, It uses Exploration as a limited resource. Only other game I have seen pulling this of was desktop dungeons, and that was allways a tense fight there.The graphics - Lovely. Its all Pixel graphics, but they still look so Good. I mean, It is Pixels, but then again they actually look like something other than blocks.Gameplay : It takes a little getting used to, but a lot can be found out in a few sessions of trial and error. still think this needs a Tutorial and/or First Time Tutorial floor, but you can only deliver what you have and since not all systems are 100% done and are subject to change, building an extensive tutorial wuld be a bit in vain. But the system at all is simpleyou build stuff, you open a door, you see whats inside - Monsters, Relics, Survivors, Loot - and you gain resources from your built stuffI also love how they got an EXP-less Levelling system. Thats what one of the resources is for. You give them enough food, and they Level up. But the limited building space, the limited Dust to activate rooms to build stuff in them and the fact that you have 3 resources you have to take care of make this game a really hot decision sometimes.Sound - The music is Gorgeous. Need I say more? I love me some good music in gamesOverall - for an early access game it is quite good and delivers a lot of content already. a good bunch of loveable heroes, a hard make-you-thing management system and most of all, tons of Rougelike Try againsy fun, since the game may end up playing the "Diablo 2 Wheel of Skills" with you and your building/resource decision(To explain the reference, Diablo 2 was a Clicky RPG with a multitude of classes and different skills. However, most builds that bring you through the game just fall short at the final boss. Means you could breeze through the game with a necromancer summoning skelettons wreaking havoc, but on the final boss they will be killed of way before they reach him. Not to forget that he one hits you as average necromancer. That boss was the "Is your Skillset viable?" moment. And no, the only way to respec was to use a trainer/Savegame editor. If you didnt want this, its start the game from scratch )

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Im major roguelike fan. My favourites include Risk of Rain, Faster Than Light and One Way Heroics, so i have some experience on the genre. But yeah, let's get to the point:In Dungeon of The Endless your goal is to escape the Underground Lab whilst defending yourself with heroes and different turrets. You start humbly, but as you make your way closer to the entrance, you'll recruit new heroes, and unlock new turrets to keep them alive. But as you grow stronger, enemies grow outright brutal, in strength, variety and sheer numbers...The game is a masterpiece. I'd recommend it to anyone who's into roguelikes, towerdefence or dungeon crawling. If you're into 2 or more of those categories, you should have alredy bought the game just to see what you're missing.Here are the pros and cons of the game:+ Art style is unique and pretty.+ Music is great.+ Gameplay is innovative and fresh.+ Glitches are extremely rare.+ The story is interesting (if you care to search for it), as are the interactions between playable characters (heroes).+ Amazing replayability.+ Micromanagement. Doing one thing over and over might get you trough couple floors, but after that the enemies will slaughter you. So it's important to keep in mind what kind of enemies the floor in question hosts, and what turrets work on them.- Some of the heroes would need some balancing work. (Im looking at you, Max and Josh)- The luck factor. As with all roguelikes, sometimes the game just kills you without giving you even slightest chance. This becomes apparent, when you're on the last level, and game refuses to give you any Dust (resource required to power your defences), and then steamrolling you with first big enemy wave.Long story short, I still love the game. 130+ hours played, and I have yet to clear the Sanitary pod (hard mode). Update, Sanitary Pod cleared with around 140 hours.Rating:9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Rogue Like Dungeon crawler.You end up on this planet after "your" (aka the ship you were on as staff or prisoner) prison ship got attacked and destroyed. Dont worry you managed to launch a escape pod and escape death... for now.Your only option once landed with 2 survivors is to open the door out the unknown... with a minor hope of a ticket somewhere away from this dangerous place.Economy is split between Four things.Food to level and heal your heroes.Science to remove cooldown on abilites or research new modules that will make your journey easier (to make it possible that you might survive without good luck or being veteran to the game)building material (dont recall correct term) That you build modules that increases one of these three or many minor one with offensive defensive or boosts to the room you build them in.And finally we have Dust... Your best friend. Without this materia darkness will consume the entire level. Also the merchants love Dust since it is also the currency in this game. So will you spend some dust to buy a new weapon or armor? Or will you light another room so unknown lurkers cant spawn there to attack you that might occur when you open up yet another door into the unknown? The option is yours, but know this; To many dark rooms will for certain mean a bigger fight once they come... And they will come for either your blood or powercrystal (your dungeonheart where dust is stored).There is currently a bunch of diffrent unique heroes(more being added all the time), you start with a few ones, all being unique. But during your journey you will run into outsiders, good and twisted characters, all ready to join you up to a party of max 4. Keep them alive for 3 levels and your permantly unlock them for your next round... which open up the game depth even more. The levels is randomized, however the number of doors isnt. (currently)This game currently in beta, the devs got a very clear structure of what they want to do and they have frequently updates for the game.  You shouldnt be to worried about this game not being finished or ending up as a mess.Currently the game is fun enough and with more content being added it refreshes the replay value of the game.I highly doubt you gonna regret getting this game. But if your in doubt, do more research or wait until complete.Personally I recommend this game.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								Review written as of 0.1.1:This game is definitely in alpha, and, as a warning, only 3 stages of the game will feel VERY short. It only took me a couple hours to experience just about all of the in game "behind the door" events, level up all the different heroes, and unlock all the different structures currently available. Ordinarily I would not recommend this title for the average buyer, since there is so little content existing at the present moment. However, as an owner of Amplitude Studio's previous title, "Endless Space", I know this developer as a consumer-oriented, professional studio that sets deadlines and pushes themselves to continue creating content for their games well past the "we could just abandon the game, take the money, and run" phase. I have lots of confidence that the content will continue coming. You will just have to be patient for crucial game elements like the whole research system, all character abilities, the full character roster, DEAR GOD MORE FLOORS PLZ AMPLITUDE, etc...The graphics and colors of this game are very pleasing to the eye, and shadows look great. FlyByNo is an AMAZING in-house composer, and his work on this game is just as great as his work on Endless Space. I do not know who does the writing at Amplitude but whoever it is, they put such flavor into every tooltip, every item description in all their games that you'll find yourself reading every word that finds its way onto your screen, no matter how dull you may expect the description for an item like "T-Shirt" to be. The founder edition comes with 50% coupons for Endless Space and the new Endless Space expansion (since buying the Disharmony expansion was in my plans already, this practically offset the cost difference between a Founder's Edition and Pixel Edition alone) for a total of about $20 in savings. The Founder's Edition itself costs $20 normally ($15 on sale now) so if you were actually thinking about buying Endless Space and it is not on sale, you may as well buy a Founder's Edition of Dungeon of the Endless and apply the discounts to maximize your Steam Wallet.In short, this is a fun and unique game with lots of easily visible potential that it doesn't live up to yet. If you are not confident in this developer's ability to deliver content steadily and stay committed to their titles, you will likely feel ripped off for the amount of content currently available and I'd recommend waiting for an official, non-early release. Otherwise, you'll enjoy this, but slowly, and you will wish there was more content available just because you're so enticed by what already exists.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless, to put it simply, does everything right.At its heart, Dungeon of the Endless is a relatively generic hero-based tower defense game. You defend your core node against spawning armies of increasing difficulty while building modules to defend and support your heroes. If this was all Dungeon of the Endless was, it would really just be another Kongregate tower defense game.However, the mechanic that Amplitude chose to focus their core gameplay on is exploration, and what a glorious implementation it is.  I've always been a fan of games that use exploration as a resource mechanic. I enjoy puzzle games and this one simple mechanic can turn nearly any game into thought-provoking puzzler.The premise of the game is simple. You're on a ship and you crash land. The only thing salvageable from your ship is a power source. You need to protect this power source and drag it through each of the levels until you reach the top and can be rescued.Of course, it's not that simple.Dungeon of the Endless uses a resource system comprised of industry (for building things), science (for learning how to build things), and food (for keeping your dudes alive and leveling up). You gain these resources by opening doors (exploration). There is also a concept of Dust as a resource, which you find in some rooms or from some monsters. By allocating Dust, you can light up different rooms in the level. Lighting up rooms does a few things: powers your devices in the room and prevents monsters from spawning. However, you don't have enough Dust to light every room, so it becomes a puzzle of what rooms to light up and/or occupy to minimize the spawning enemies. When you do find the level's exit and you plan to try to move your power source to it, the fun truly happens. From every dark room, enemies constantly spawn. The person carrying the crystal moves at half speed, so it's up to everyone else to defend that person until they reach the exit and your team can leave the level.Speaking of your team, you start with two dudes. They all have different abilities and different stats. Over the course of the game, you can use food to level up your guys (up to a max of level 15) which helps their stats, gives them new abilities, etc.All of these concepts work completely and are executed flawlessly. There is a sense of constant panic and dread when you're exploring, particularly when you're short on resources or dust. You want to spend resources to improve your team, but want to save some for emergencies. If I have a complaint about the game is that it's a bit too easy. Once you understand the fundamentals of the game and have a good strategy, it pays to just keep repeating that strategy for the entire game. However, the developers very intelligently added a variety of ships that change the rules of the game. This is where the future challenge lies.One of the best titles in recent memory. Well worth the low price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless is a beautiful mash up of different genres that is really hard to identify.It is a rogue lite, tower defense, survival, resource management game with a bit of rpg thrown in, let me elaborate more.You begin the game after you choose your starting party of two people, these characters are the survivors of an attack at your ship near a mysterious planet. You choose a pod your heroes escaped in, which dramatically changes the rules of the dungeon, and off you go in your emergency landing, deep inside this strange complex. From there on, your only chance to escape the planet, is to carry your crystal from the damaged pod up to the surface. You have to use elevators to do this, they effectively mark the start and the end of each level. The game consists in exploring every floor searching for the exit, but also for resources, merchants, weapons, other survivors or who knows what your next objective might be. In the meantime, your dust reserve is used to power up the complex while you explore, because dark areas spawn monsters, and monsters have a nasty habit of wanting to break your crystal... so what do you do? You build minor modules to protect the path you carve in the complex, you build major modules to help you attain resources every door you open, you research new or upgraded versions of the modules you can build and onward to adventure. As for your heroes, every character has his set of skills, level up progression, statistics and possible equipment slots, which promotes customization and adaptability. The game has two levels of difficulties, one is doable, the other one is pretty tough.Of course the game has tons of replay value, everything being randomized except items, modules and heroes, every room and branching is randomized so there is no chance you will have the same game twice, even the merchants sell not only different stuff, but even accept a random resource for trade. The multiplayer is great but I suggest grabbing a friend since this a highly strategical game, more than an action one, but I've met my fair share of reasonable people online.If that wasn't enough, we are talking about the Endless lore, the same you find on Endless Space and Endless Legend, which is really cool if you're fan of the work Amplitude is doing, even the resources represent the FIDS system from the game (Food, Industry, Dust, Science).Overall I had a blast with this little title, I wasn't even expecting much but it became one of my favorite indie rogue like titles really fast. Not everyone appreciates it though (like one of my friends) though I still can't understand him, this game has everything one could ever hope for, it's original and cheap too!------------------------------------------EDIT : My nominee for The “Just 5 More Minutes” Award, since I always relax and sink in this more time than I realize.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												A unique combination of roguelite, dungeon-crawler, and tower defense. Definitely worth a look. I love the graphics, and the music even more. If you own Endless Space and/or Endless Legend (Amplitude's other games), then it's worth it to buy the upgraded editions, as there's some unique content available by owning those other games. If you buy the upgraded editions of those games, you'll get added content for buying Dungeon of the Endless! None of it's essential, but some of it's fun.I've played over 50 hours of the game and have unlocked all but 1 character, and only half of the pods (the 'ship' you start in--various pods alter the starting conditions and change the rules throughout the course of the game). There's plenty of content, and the formula works well enough to provide hours of gameplay. For some real fun and chaos, just add friends! You can't pause in multiplayer, and with 4 players, everyone controls their own character, making coordination vital and extremely fun, especially if you can get some voice chat going (which is easy now that steam's voice chat is pretty damn good these days.)*One thing to be aware of: You do not directly control the actions of your characters, nor do you directly engage in combat! You click to open doors, interact with NPCs and objects, and move from room to room. The characters will automatically attack enemies based on certain priorities. You can activate your abilities on command, but that's it. When I bought it, I thought you controlled your characters like in Diablo or League of Legends or Dota, but that isn't the case and I was majorly turned off. But I quickly discovered that the more hands-off control lend itself very well to this game and quickly picked up on it and started having a blast!9.5/10, would recommend. I subtracted .5 only because there are a couple minor annoyances regarding controls: I wish you could assign all your heroes' abilities each their own keybind. As it is, you have to select that hero and then press a key (or click an icon) to activate the ability. It's fine in singleplayer when you can pause it, but in MP when you're controller 2-3 heroes at once, it can be a pain in real-time.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								Unlike a lot of "Early Access" games, v0.1.1 of Dungeon of The Endless feels like a relatively complete game.  It's stable and has a great mix of overall game mechanics that work well to produce a coherent game.  To try to describe this game in conventional terms might just confuse you.  Yes, it has aspects of roguelike games, real time strategy games, role playing games, tower defense games, and board games.  Personally, I think of it as mostly a board game with each "turn" divided into a time before you open another door, which will reveal treasure, a merchant, waves of enemies, blueprints, or something else - you never know!  Then it's a mad scramble reminiscent of a real time strategy/tower defensive hybrid to keep everything upright until the next turn.  When deciding who to level up or equip with gear, that's where the RPG aspect enters the picture.This board-game like mechanic can be a good thing because it introduces a lot of interesting choices.  If I assign my hero here, will they be able to make it back to where they need to be if enemies appear there?  Do I spend my industry points on producing more industry points, producing things I need, or do I try to scimp on points now so I have more avaialble to use on the next map?  Do I invest my dust in that great piece of equipment, or is it more important that I power rooms?  These choices are clever in that many of them are just comprimises; there's often not a "right" choice, just a good guess at what might work out in the long run.  I like a game that makes me think.  Yet, Endless Dungeon is rarely ever overwhelming, just rich with important choices to make and requiring you pay attention when your heroes are fighting so they don't get slain needlessly.  It's quite remarkable they consider this quite-playable product such an early version.  True, you're limited to just three (four?) random map levels per game (which you can exhaust in an hour), there's not yet skills on the heroes, the tech tree systems isn't in yet, and so on.  Yet, the game is more complete than many $15 titles I've bought.  Amplitude studios seems to know what they're doing, and if they call this version v0.1.x, then it's clear this game should be of staggering, epic proportions if they see their plans through to completion.

Early Access Review
								What a wonderful roguelike comboed with tower defense.  Even in Alpha this is as stable and playable as Endless Space was on release.  Amplitude had my trust after Endless Space which is why I risked an Alpha purchase.  Not disappointed.  You start with two heroes.  They have skills, inventory and slots of weapon/armour/tool.  Each room you clear gives you the next wave of resources which you can use to level your heroes, build or research.  You can have your heroes man stations that you build in each room to vary your resource income if you can do without them.  So you have to manage your heroes and incoming enemies.  That's the basics of it.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Pretty addictive. It's a fairly unique combination of genres - I'd call it primarly a resource management/tower defense game with roguelike elements and some RPG mixed in rather than a roguelike with TD elements, but that's just me.+ High replayability - unlockable ships (influences how you start as well as your strategy throughout) unlockable characters, randomized maps, loot and research opportunities makes each playthrough different.+ "One more turn/game" appeal - whether I was trying out a recent unlock or simply trying to correct the mistakes I made last game, I found myself wanting more.+ Challenging without being unfair, tactical without being overwhelming - this game can slap you into the dirt, but when you lose it tends to be because of your own actions rather than RNG. And while there are enough mechanics in play to make the game interesting and intense, you won't find yourself lost. You die, you do better. You die, you do better.+ Good sound/music. Not much else to say.- Ugly. If you're used to roguelikes you'll be expecting this, and if you're like me you'll get so immersed that you'll forget it's ugly entirely. But, when hordes of enemies are streaming in and you can only recognize a few distict shapes in the pack, you'll wish it was just a tad better. Still, very minor.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Dungeon of the Endless is a top-down roguelike dungeon exploration & tower defense game with many unlockable elements set in the Endless game universe.The player uses a squad of up to 4 characters to explore a multi-floor dungeon one room at a time while protecting a power crystal. Like other Endless games, the four resources are Food, Industry, Dust, and Science (FIDS). With each door opened, more FIDS accumulate, but dangerous monsters may spawn. Players eventually discover a dungeon floor exit and carry the crystal to a new dungeon floor, continuing on until the game ends at the 12th floor.Characters may be discovered in-game and unlocked after completing a certain number of floors with that character. Characters have different strengths as might be expected, including attack power, defense, movement speed, and "wit", which in this game translates into better module operation bonuses. Certain secret combinations of characters lead to different in-game events.Food, Industry, and Science increase in a predictable fashion with each door opened, but Dust is less predictable and cannot be saved between levels. Dust may sometimes be discovered in new rooms or obtained after defeating monsters.Rooms adjacent to the crystal may be powered (or "lit") subject to a limit based on the current amount of Dust. Lit rooms do not spawn monsters. Given enough industry, different "modules" may be built in a powered room based on the characteristics of that room--not every room can hold a module, no room can hold more than one "major module", and different rooms have different limits for "minor modules".Items may be discovered in new rooms and are bought and sold for FIDS at merchants which may be discovered in new rooms.A special Research module may appear in a new room, allowing for Science to be invested to unlock new modules or higher levels of existing modules.Modules may be removed, for example removing an unneeded Research module to make room.Like any great game, Dungeon of the Endless presents the player with many interesting choices, for example:- leave a room dark to spawn more monsters and the chance for more Dust, or light the room to reduce monster spawn and provide room for modules?- invest Industry in FIDS-producing modules (longer-term payoff) or defensive modules (immediate payoff)?- spend Food to recruit a new character, or save Food to see if a better choice is available later?- take the exit as soon as it is found, or open a few more doors to try to gain more Food, Industry, and Science for the next level?- invest Science now, or remove the Science module in favor of a different major module?Tactical elements include: positioning of characters when unlocking a door, character movement between rooms during combat, activation of special abilities, healing (which takes Food), and resetting abilities (which takes Science) in combat. Combat may be paused for easier micro-management, but some players will find it more fun to do without pausing (there's even a Steam Achievement for beating a dungeon without pausing).

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												This game is hard, relentless, unforgiving, incredibly fun, addictive and has tons of replayability.  I personally think this game is a hard to learn, hard to master type game.  This game is not for the weak-willed who seek handholding, checkpoints or walks in the park.  Dungeon of the Endless is a tower defence game that draws RPG, rogue-like, dungeon crawling and resource management elements.  You start each game by picking 2 heroes out of a 24 (with all of DLC and unlockable characters) member cast.  Each hero has different stats that help your team in one way or another (Speed, Power, Health, and Wit).  Your objective is to look for the exit of the floor, which leads to the next floor.  Each floor gets progressively harder and harder the further down you go.  To "win" or complete the game, you have to complete all 12 floors.  You start each floor in a single room and have up to 4 different directions you can go.  Each room you enter has a chance to spawn dust (used to powers rooms) as well as: other resources, merchants, treasure (that can be worn for bonuses or sold for resources), other heroes to add to your team (for a max of 4 heroes per team) and/or monsters!  For each room you enter, any room you do not have powered by dust has a chance to spawn monsters in it.  You will eventually come to a point where the minority of your rooms will be powered and lots of monsters are spawning.  This is where strategy and micro-managing your heroes comes into play.  You have to find the perfect setup where you can defend all your modules and your crystal, without your heroes dying.  This will require quick thinking, quick calculations and quick action to make sure you can defend all directions without losing modules, heroes or resources.  If you lose (from either monsters taking your crystal down or losing all your heroes), you do not start from where you left off, you will need to start from floor one again with a new team.I’ve read a ton of negative reviews saying this game has way too much RNG to be recommended.  You can definitely be ♥♥♥♥ed over by RNG in this game, but 90% of the time you have that bad of RNG, it’s definitely winnable if you just play your heroes and defence right.  The feeling of conquering an insanely hard floor after getting some bad RNG is pure bliss.  I recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging game or a completely new take on tower defence.  You will lose NUMEROUS times before you finally win (on Easy at least), but that first victory is one to remember.  If you’re looking to start playing this game, I’d highly recommend checking out the let’s play link below.  This video really helped me understand the basics when I was first starting out.  


YouTube™ Video: Let's Look At: Dungeon of the Endless 

			Views: 202,143		

			Dungeon of the Endless on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/249050/ Dungeon of the Endless is a dungeon crawling roguelite with a fusion of strategy, RPG, and tower defense mechanics.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game just proves that you don't need a powerful graphic engine to make a potentially great game. The interface is intuitive and the style is rich enough to give you an artgasm. The game itself has a fairly easy objective - get your dust-filled crystal thing to an exit. But don't be fooled by the simplicity, the game can be punishing. When you take the crystal out of its notch, be prepared to face continous waves of enemies. It's difficult in a sense that it'll force you to utilize anything at your disposal in favor of just making a run for it. It's a game that will test your attention as well as your ability to make tough strategic choices.If you're sick and tired of shooters, consider picking up this game. It's colorful, easy to pick up and incredibly easy on the eyes.

												As a recent release, I  have found this to be my favourite game so far this month, the gameplay is unique, and a good combination of genres.The music is wonderful, the characters are different and offer a variety of combinations of skills. The only negative thing I'd have to say about this game is the multiplayer, at times can be very unstable. If this is fixed in any coming updates I'd have no complaints about this game. The difficulty is just right, and rewarding and I can't wait to see if we get even more brutal difficulties to truly test our sanity and endurance. Some would say the dust generation is unbalanced, but I find it just right, of having to choose between fully exploring or just blizting it before i lose any (more) characters. To any of my friends who even reads this, you totally gotta get it for such a cheap game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Loving this game so far. I have both Endless Space and Endless Legend, and I think they both show promise, but ultimately aren't quite 'there' yet. But with this game, they've taken the world, the lore, and the feel, as well as some of the concepts (resources) and applied them in a VERY different package. This is part RPG, part tower defence, all fun!Graphics style works, and the game has a feel that is reminiscent of the wonderful iPad game - Sword & Sworcery. Pixel graphics that really work, a wonderful, atmospheric soundtrack. Really solid.And the game play is wonderful (albeit hard - i'm playing on the easiest setting and still finding it a real challenge to get a decent strategy). You'll need to be a little patient, but use those defences and you'll get there. A wonderful example of how a simple concept, well executed, can be delightfully engaging. Well done dev team, well done!

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												The title is wrong, as these dungeons are not endless. Unless play it in endless mode... Yeah.Well, it's a roguelike rpg dungeon crawler with tower-defense elements. You crash into some shiттy place and you got this cristal, right? Well, you need to carry that cristal all the way to the elevator, which you have to find in a first place, as you have no way of knowing what will expect you in the next door. Maybe it's loot room, maybe it's full of enemies, maybe there is another character inside that you can recruit for your group, maybe I'll go and fцск myself... You just don't know. And thats the fun part of this game. Get your group, explore the dungeon and try to get to the end. I suggest to reinforce your path to the elevator with turrets of all sorts, as things will get really bad really fast once you remove the cristal from the previous spot. This game has a good price-replayability ratio and it's a wise purchase, if you are a fan of roguelike games or tower defense ones. Fun to play it in coop with your friends too. I give it 8 of 10 and now I am going to cry myself to sleep. Have a nice day, anonymous reader.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												Before buying this game, keep in mind that, unlike what you might think from the description, this is not a very complex rogue-like. While there are elements of tower defense, resource management, and levelled characters, there is little learning curve, meaningful decisions, or stat mongering in the game.In short, it's much closer to a mobile game for PC than it is to NetHack. Which is absolutely fine, just something to keep in mind before purchasing.POSITIVES:- Immediately accessible from the first level- Meaningful replayability via different starting conditions and Endless Mode- Enjoyable world characterization - Crisp assembly- FunSOMEWHAT NEGATIVES:- Fairly easy. I beat the hardest starting difficulty in three tries, and each scenario in one or two- RPG elements are a little dull- Individual levels often end anti-climatically- Exploration lacks variety- No voice actingBOTTOME LINE:This is a great little game that's perfect for killing idle hours. If the description intrigues you, it delivers. (But just don't expect a game of great depth.) A sequal would be fantastic.---PLEASE NOTE BEFORE PLAYING:This game comes with a free DLC that adds four Team Fortress characters to the game. This is pretty fun when you're used to the game, but it ruins the atmosphere to run across a Heavy or Pyro during your first couple playthroughs. I'd reccommend unchecking the DLC box on the game's page in your library before launching, and turning it on after a couple hours to see if you like it.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												This is an amazing game.I've put over a hundred hours in so far, and there's no end in sight. I CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME HIGHLY ENOUGH!!! It's still being supported and actively expanded by the developer, which is always nice. The latest expansion pack with the Rescue Team is still a mystery to me. I haven't explored all the content, or discovered the storyline reasons for each character's presence. But I expect good, high quality content, which is what I've received with this game so far.My only issue with this game is that it's STILL buggy as hell. It WILL regularly crash on you and/or devour your saves and leave you with only a fading memory of those 11 floors you and your buddy put in on Easy mode, escaping death by a fingernail's breadth. Then *POOF* the game takes a crap on you. This WILL happen. I personally think the game is worth putting up with this stuff, but I can see why it would put some people off. All this being said, this game has many hours of fun dungeon delving for you to enjoy. The randomization is sometimes cruel, but overall the game is reasonably well balanced. Some characters are quantitatively better than others, pure and simple. But there's enough variation in the character skills to make trying each one out something you'll want to try. Especially with the expansion content, there's significantly altered mechanics.Finally, PLEASE play this game in multiplayer a couple times. It's a fantastic experience that you won't forget. You and up to 3 friends will be pitted against the dungeon together, which is what friends are all about. When you do this, I recommend that you learn how to manually back up your own saves. It's just too painful to lose a game to a corrupt save, or a de-sync glitch, or any number of other things. Just don't use it to cheat, please.This game is one of my top five favorite plays right now. I recommend you try it too!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2015
												It's time to toss in my two cents.At first I was like - Dungeon of the Endless gets me some free stuff for other games I own from Amplitude Studios, and I get to support them. Cool.Then I played it and lost a lot. I suck at Rogue-like games. So I put it away.A few months pass, and a Steam friend of mine invites me to play with him via MP (he's in France). 5 hours later, and I see the allure, but I still suck in SP. SO, DotE gets shelved again. A few more months pass and I need to write a Friday eXcurision for eXplorminate and here is the product (http://explorminate.net/2015/09/11/friday-excursion-dungeon-of-the-endless/). That results in me playing the iPAD version, and I finally learn how to play the game.So, how is the game? FUN. But it's hard, and brutal, but if you plan ahead and prepare, you can do fine on the Very Easy level, which is actually normal to hard. Easy is anything but, and don't get me started on the hard mode (you need a special pod for that). On to the review!!!You start the game as a survivor of a crashed escape pod on Auriga where the Endless were conducting experiemnts on live subjects in a crazy torture lab/arena. THe planet is like Mortal Kombat world and this is where the combatants are made.  Anyways, as you try to escape the labs to the surface, you face monsters and random events every time you open a door...  Why do you open doors? to search for the escape elevator. Each time you open the door, you get resources that you can use to upgrade your heroes, power and buildup your rooms, and investigate tech to further your modules.You repeat the above for 12 floors until you find the exit, and all the while, you'll be attacked by hordes of monsters.Let me repeat this point - the game is BRUTAL in SP, and equally BRUTAL in MP, but at least there, you get to lose together with your friends.I recommend this title, because it fantastic, and Amplitude Studios has just released a 3rd, that's right, count it.  1.. 2... 3... free dlc adding content.Have fun dying, I know I did.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Fun, simple, but very hard dungeon exploration/survival/tower defense game. You have maxium of 4 heroes that explore dungeon level by level, trying to find elevator to the next level. Dungeon is built out of rooms, and uou open up doors which represent turns. Each turn you gain resources that you use to build modules and towers, research new things, level up and heal heroes. While exploring, you encounter hordes of monsters spawning out of darkness, which will try to kill you and your core, which you need to protect to get out of the dungeon.Like all Endless games, this game as well is meant to be replayed again and again, with different settings, like characters or core-mechanics that you unlock by playing the game.For a casual scrub like me, the game is definitely too hard on easy difficulty, but challenging enough on "Too Easy" difficulty.Even though I haven't been able to beat the game on easy difficulty, I recommend it. It looks good, it sounds good, and it's fun to play. There is also multiplayer which is big bonus for a co-op fan like me!

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fantastic art direction - mediocre gameplay.A game that (currently) isn't the sum of its parts. All the elements are there, apart from something compelling to do when you play it. The concept is original enough, but the execution is in turns tedious, repetitive and unfair. Playing simply involves repeating the same actions, stage after stage, and hoping the RNG doesn't screw you too badly.Unlike true Rogue-likes such as FTL and Binding of Isaac, this is essentially a very pretty, but basic, tower defence game with occasional difficulty spikes, or loot drops, as its 'random' element. None of these are compelling like Spelunky's altars or shopkeepers, or FTL's story choices, but simple occasional resource gifts or monster waves.The problem here is that it misjudges what makes tower defence fun - accurately managing those resources. By tying those into the RNG (level layout strongly dictates your defences and resource gathering) your strategy is always a slave to the RNG, and can often be ruined simply by an obnoxious layout simply starving you of resources, or forcing you to defend more points than is possible.This makes the game a case of going through the motions, repeating an optimal strategy with little breathing room for experimentation, until you luck into a good run or are forced into an unfair loss. All 10 stages play exactly the same, but just get larger and contain more damaging enemies. Once you've finished stage 1, you've essentially seen the entire game.A shame, as every other element is dripping with style and polish, and the mixture of TD, dungeon crawling and Rouge-like works as a proof of concept, but unfortunately all you get here is simply a marriage of extremely shallow reprentations of all three genres.6/10

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even after I bought this game, and invested a few hours into it, these previews inspire me to want to play it even more.  So if I had to sum up this review into 3 words, it would be this:  Buy this game.Luckily, I don't, so I won't!.... Maybe I shoulda saved that for the tl;dr.  And yes, there is a tl;dr, so scroll down if you hate words.So after like a 30 second little intro, which you can totally skip, you get thrown straight into the game.  Which is nice because when you die, restarting takes like 0(thats a zero) time at all.  And oh yes, there will be much death.Now normally, when you play a game, and you die a lot, you aren't usually having a lot of fun.  Well thats totally not the case in this game.  Although the game is still in early access, that means it might be 30% completed if we're lucky, it still manages to entertain.When you die, you start over, and you take what you learned and apply it to the new run.  In all honesty, I have only made it past the 5th floor once.  And... the 4th floor once....  And the 3rd floor twice... on the easiest game setting.   XDWhen you start the game you pick two heroes you want to take with you, considering right now you only have 3 to choose from, it's not that hard of a choice.  As you progress through the game you'll meet other heroes that can you hire with food, so try to keep a surplus at all times because you don't want to miss out on adding a massochistic marine, or a crazy short guy with a sword twice his size to your team.  I've only managed to unlock two characters so far personally.Other things you will run across are artifacts which for research points, you can add new modules to your list of goodies, or even upgrade existing ones.  Really awesome, hope to find these early on in a level.  In rare cases, you can even find two in the same level, which when that happens, is like winning the god damned lotto.And without further ado, lets get down to the nitty gritty of this review.The Good:  This is the most awesome sci-fi rogue-like turret defensesque RPG squad based retro dungeon crawl game I have ever played.The So-So:  This is the only sci-fi rogue-like turret defensesque RPG squad based retro dungeon crawl game I have ever played.The Bad:  It is not a *multiplayer* sci-fi rogue-like turret defensesque RPG squad based retro dungeon crawl game.(yet)Lets expand on the Bad:  There is no multiplayer, there is no story, there is no tech tree, and thus is no substance.Lets expand on the So-So:  Mulstiplayer is grayed out, the tech tree is grayed out, the story has not been added, the substance does not exist yet.Lets expand on the Good:  There WILL be multi-player, there WILL be a story and quests, there WILL be a tech tree like thingy; and what does this add to this already awesome sci-fi rogue-like turret defensesque RPG squad based retro dungeon crawl game?  The most badass thing I have bought in years, duh!All in all, even if you don't like sci-fi rogue-like turret defensesque RPG squad based retro dungeon crawl games(You sick of me saying this yet?  I'm not!), you'll still probably like this one.Oh, and incase you are wondering why I didn't review things like music, graphics, gameplay, or anything else like that, that normal people review, well lemme sum it up for you.Graphics:  It's pixelated.  What more do you expect?Music:  It's very ambiant, changes when things happen, all in all, not the best or the worst, though not sure how it could be better.Gameplay:  It's in Early Access, gameplay is subject to change.  Duh.So to sum it all up, for those of you who hate words, I present:The TL;DR: Buy this game.[Hint] I said it earlier in this review.Sci-fi rogue-like turret defensesque RPG squad based retro dungeon crawl game! ( because I couldn't think of a better way to end this review!)

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dungeon of the Endless is an interesting new title by Amplitude Studios currently in Alpha development which spans several popular genres.For my full featured review with pictures and videos coming soon please visit http://progamereviews.com/review/dungeon-endless/You begin Dungeon of the Endless with two hero characters and a crystal in a small escape pod. The basic premise of the game is to explore each dungeon and find the exit. Each dungeon is comprised of interconnected randomly generated rooms. Many of these rooms contain mobs of monsters that attempt to end your game by either killing your heroes or your crystal. As you explore the dungeon's rooms you acquire resources and have the ability use these resources to deploy defenses. Game play is actually a hybrid of real time and turn based strategy in that you have the ability to pause live game play and issue commands if you so desire. The game can also be played in real time mode exclusively. Once the exit is located, your job is to transport the crystal safely there. If you make it you win the round and move on to the next level. If your heroes die, you lose. If your crystal’s dust level (essentially health, power and currency all in one) falls to zero, you lose. Piece of cake right? WRONG.Dungeon of the Endless has a lot of things going on. At its heart, it is a rouge like (hate that term) dungeon crawler. You explore a procedurally generated environment with a small group of  playable heroes. What that means is this: the dungeons and encounters are never exactly the same. Sure you’ll see similarities, but by and large the environments will never be exactly alike. Additionally, your band of motley heroes isn’t invincible. Once they die, they’re dead… FOREVER. Kiss all that experience and loot goodbye! Rogue like game play; check.So what else does the game offer? How about some resource management? In Dungeon of the Endless your success or failure is largely linked to your resource acquisition and management. There are four main resources to worry about: Dust (no you can't snort it), Industry, Food and Science. Every time you open a room you receive an amount of each resource except dust. Additionally, you can deploy resource modules in powered rooms (more on that later) that add a modifier to the amount of a particular resources obtained when subsequent doors are opened. For example, an Industry module will provide additional industry every time you open a new door. Heroes with the required skill can even operate the module and provide an additional, additional bonus to the resources. Phew, that sounds complicated. Of note here is that extra resources, except dust, are carried over to the next dungeon.Dungeon of the Endless also has Role Playing and Character Progression aspects. Even though the game features permadeath you have the ability to level up your hero's and outfit them with gear discovered in dungeons. Your heroes have stats which increase as their levels increase. In addition, as you level up your heroes they gain access to special combat skills.But wait, there's more...Dungeon of the Endless also offers tower defense like game play. As you explore each dungeon level you "open up" additional parts of the map. Each new room traversed is dark, which means it is currently not powered. These darkened rooms serve as spawn points for mobs of monsters which attack in waves and make a beeline toward your crystal. How do you stop these waves of monsters you ask? Well, you power some of these dark rooms with part of your limited supply of dust. Once powered, you then use your Industry resource to build defenses. As waves of enemies appear, your smartly placed defenses and heroes take them out. Sounds kinda tower defense like huh.One of Amplitude Studios goals is community involvement. Amplitude wants the players to take an active part in the game's development and it is facilitating this by utilizing a system called GAMES2GETHER . One of the biggest reasons to play an early access game is to participate in the evolution of a game. Plenty of Steam early access games claim to use player feedback to help shape the final product into what the community wants... and then promptly don't. Amplitude appears to actually be following through with it. By utilizing it's G2G Votes system, the community has the ability to vote on art and game design decisions. For example, the current vote is for creating a new playable character. There is also a standard forum where players can follow the games development and post their questions and comments. The jury is still out on how much the community will drive development however so we'll have to monitor the process and see how it goes.Like every other game out there, Dungeon of the Endless is not perfect. I'll cover what I feel are weak points for the game first. The game needs a lot more explanation. This is a reasonably complex game and the current tutorial slides just don't cut it. I found myself with more questions than answers after the tutorial and had to stumble into them myself. A proper tutorial level guiding the player through the games nuisances would help to acclimate players better. As this is just the alpha stage, i'm sure the developers will address this in the near future. The graphics are basic. Again, this is by design but worth noting anyway.Another issue is repetitiveness. Although the levels are procedurally generated they all look and feel essentially the same. This in addition to the fact that the basic game play remains the same can make the game feel a bit tedious after a while.  Is there an end to the game or is it truly endless? I don't actually know the answer to that question. But if the game had milestones or varied locations to make you feel like your progressing it might help. Its worth noting that in general I usually don't play rogue like games specifically for this reason. As an old school RPG and MMORPG player, I tend to become attached to my characters and devote a good amount of time carefully picking their skills and equipment. The permadeath aspect of these games is a turn off for me. I like to feel that i'm making progress towards a larger goal and I just didn't feel it with this game.All that being said, I still really like the game. Dungeon of the Endless is a fun and reasonably deep game. What's most impressive is the games complexity despite its current Alpha state. There's enough depth and strategy here already to keep you playing the game and checking back to see how it evolves. Also, at this point in my life, I tend to be gravitating towards games that i can play in small chunks. Dungeon of the Endless gives players the ability to save and pause games at any time. If your a new parent like me, trying to juggle work, parenthood, and everything else life throws at you, this is HUGE. For the price of entry, Dungeon of the Endless is definitely forth a look.

Early Access Review
								This game is in my opinion very hard. And sometimes very frustrating.Goal is pretty simple in theory. You open doors, get ressources for every door opened. You find exit, take crystal to exit. Monsters try to kill you, especially when you try to take the crystal with you.To help you, you can Upgrade rooms with ressource Harvesters, or defensive stuff.You have a team of up to 4 players, starting with 2. If you loose one he is completly gone. This was a reason for me to start over again sometimes (except these times I could recruit another one right away). Early Access Review
								Even in its current limited state, the core gameplay here is fantastic. I've already got my $10 worth out of this game, can't wait to see what it's like when it's complete.This isn't an action-heavy TD click-fest, and you won't be controlling your party of heroes in combat directly— you move them to a room and they auto-attack. Most of the strategy comes from deciding which order to open rooms, which rooms to keep powered to prevent spawns, and funneling everything else through deadly fortified chokepoints of doom. Once you've got that strategy down, you'll consistently beat the 3 levels on offer in the alpha.That being said, it is challenging, and I'm rally looking forward to later levels and added events that force tougher decisions. I think this game is going to come together nicely.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I picked up this game when it was back in Early Alpha, and at the time it felt a bit feature-scant. However, they have since gone into Beta, and I can safely say that this is worth every cent.DotE is best summarized as a mix between a roguelike, turn-based strategy game, and a sort of tower defense. Your goal is to open doors in the dungeon so that you can find the exit and then you have to carry your power source (a crystal) to that exit without it getting destroyed by the various monsters that inhabit the dungeon. The learning curve is a bit steep at first, but once you figure out how everything works, this game becomes incredibly fun.There are some drawbacks, such as the technical glitches, occasional crashes (at least for me), and some balance issues, but the devs are highly involved in the community and are taking steps to actively address these issues - more than I can say for other Early Access games.You can find yourself sinking a lot of time into this game if you take the time to enjoy it. I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is an Early Access Review, so read with that in mind.Dungeon of The Endless, portrayed as a ''Roguelike Dungeon-Defender" game. Roguelike seems to be more equivalent with ''PermaDeath'' these days than actual Roguelikes, because *real* Roguelikes these days are rare. While Dungeon of the Endless *does* kind of fall flat in that department, the gameplay and visuals are still great and the game is a joy to play.What do you do?You crashlanded on a planet in your escape pod. Two of your crew members survived but the escape pod is totally ruined. It is up to you to exit the space shuttle, explore the hallways of some unknown facility, and escape with the power core that still happened to be intact. It is reminiscent of tower-defense games, in that there is a distinct turn-based mechanic going on in-between the real time segments. Every time you explore a new room, you get additional resources plus a chance to spawn some event. There's an event for the room you just entered (Resources / Items / Monsters / Nothing / NPCs) and a possible event for several rooms that have been exploded and abandoned (Monster spawns).As soon as you open a door to explore a new room, you potentially trigger a ''tower defense wave''. If nothing happens? Lucky you! Continue to build / scout / play around and open another door.The power core itself also plays a role, with its health being shared as both currency and power-limiter, you will have to keep it safe to ensure the option of building a safe route throughout the dungeons that you will be exploring. Almost every room has a specific amount of small nodes and big nodes which can be used to build towers that either attack, help defend, or give other supportive boons that affect either your heroes or the resource generation per room explored.Although the Early Access is relatively limited, it is already noticeable that a lot of work went into this game, and as far as I can tell, it should only get better and better as time goes on.The only downsides for the early access (other than limited content) are the few bugs, of which some can be quite annoying (and even gamebreaking at times) They happen sparingly though, and with the dedication Amplitude has shown on their other games, this should get fixed relatively fast.So, would I recommend this game?If you are looking for an *actual* Roguelike in the same style as NetHack / ADOM / mAngband, then no.If you are looking for a fun strategical Tower Defense meets Dungeon Crawler RPG game, then it's an absolute yes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												The best implementation of a co-op Roguelike that I've seen. It mixes turn-based elements and real-time play, so that it's not one constant unbroken action sequence - you get downtime after each room unless you get overrun. The premise is simple: Open doors to explore the level, and beware of enemy spawns in unpowered rooms after you open each door. Find the exit, and carry your crystal from the entry point to it - but as soon as you pick it up, monsters will spawn until you escape.The lowest difficulty mode is tough, but reasonable - and there's one more above that if you're looking for a serious challenge. The descriptions of the items are humorous, the game is easy to understand, and offers a good challenge without being punishing. And it's fun on your own, but even moreso with up to three friends you can collaborate with. Highly recommended if you like Roguelikes and want to get your friends in on the action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												PROS-Diverse cast of misfits that you will lead to an inevitable demise.-Creates a wonderfully haunting sense of isolation through both the visual art style and the excellent soundtrack.-Somehow manages to blend tower defence, rts, rpg and roguelike elements together without failing at any of them.-Easy mode will ruthlessly murder your squad over and over again. -Different types of escape pods to unlock, each modifying how the game is played.-Pixellated pugs.NEUTRALS-This is definitely a roguelike, and sometimes you'll do as much as you can and still fail. Sometimes you will find the exit to the next floor in seven or eight rooms, sometimes it will be the last door on the floor. I find that being stretched thin and having to guard three fronts with a handful of turrets and heroes to be half the fun.CONS-An essential tactic for later in the game involves using heores in unpowered rooms in order to prevent enemy spawns. I'm not sure if this is mentioned anywhere in-game. I found out about it on the forums.I can't recommend this strongly enough. If you're a fan of any of the genres listed on the tags, do yourself a favour and pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
What do I rate it? A significantly high 7/10.Why?In brief; it's an amazing dungeon crawler with a tower-defense aspect seamlessly and cleverly incorporated into the fighting aspect of the game between each round of opening a new random door. You could trawl the floors for hours and spend even longer over-thinking your strategic moves between rooms. After the fourth or fifth floor, you begin to feel a familiarity building and the game slowly becomes a little repetitive. Discovering the same rooms you did two floors ago - like a treasure room, banquet surprise (food bonus), scrap parts (factory parts) and yadda yadda. So although the maps are all unique and no path is the same as the last map, you begin to build a familiarity with the small number of different custom rooms you could venture into, which to an extent, makes you feel like there's nothing new to discover and you've seen everything already. Just in a different order between the floors you take.Multiplayer is nonexistent online. I've tried searching for public matches and to no avail found any. So the multiplayer aspect would only be feesible if you had friends who also the game to play with and don't mind spending a vast amount of time on a playthrough that you can't save or return too. As of yet anyway. Overall...?Yes. It's a game that will entertain you for hours if you enjoy dungeon crawlers. Do not buy for the mulitplayer aspect, unless someone else owns the game and can be relied upon to play with you for hours at a time to even attempt to finish a playthrough. Atmospherics, music and gameplay is fairly good. Overal; buy this game when it's on sale. I wouldn't say it's worth the retail mark-up and it definitely needs a lot of rough edges smoothing out. Such as bugs and incomplete fixes. But a very promising arcade style game.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												This game is awesome! It kind of reminds me of that Space Hulk game on 3DO. I did a quick intro video for my dad, but anyone else can take a look to see what it's like. 


Dungeon of the Endless Quick Intro 
A Video of Dungeon of the Endless
By: Lauren

			First video! This is for my dad to see if he's interested in playing Dungeon of the Endless. I didn't realize I look so bored while playing games, but I swear it's super fun!		


You control up to 4 heroes with different skillsets that you can level up and equip with items you find in chests or from merchants. The goal is to find the elevator exit for each randomly generated floor, then grab your crystal and high tail it to the exit before the horde of aliens murder you.There's also a tower defense and resource management aspect to the game. You can plop down some mini turrets that either damage/debuff enemies, or buff your heroes. Opening a door to a different room is considered a turn, which grants you more resources, but also has a chance to spawn waves of enemies.There's a lot more to the game, but I recommend not looking at any guides since most of the fun comes from honing your strategy (dying over and over again) and finding out which playstyle works for you!Con:I would hold off on multiplayer until a save function is implemented. It looks like the developers are really responsive to the community, so it shouldn't be long =]. In the meantime, have fun in single player, still definitely worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
Early Access Review
								If you are on the fence between buying this game, hopefully this will help. Dungeon of the Endless is currently in ALPHA, which means it isn't a full-release game yet. You're buying into a game that isn't finished, so know what you're buying before you go rage on the forums that it was a rip-off. Now into what I saw in the game: You start off with 2 randomized heroes, with their own stats and appearance. You'll begin the game by getting as much resources as you can while trying to find the exit of the dungeon. Every door you open has a risk/reward to it,  where you could find anything from a Hero/Merchant/Food Surplus/Industry Surplus/Treasure. If you don't find those, you'll meet the baddies who have different agendas. Some might rush to your crystal in hopes of destroying it, and others will just try to pummel your hero or devices in your previously explored rooms. Now it might seem like a simple task to just go room to room and find the exit, but you're also looking at waves of monsters spawning and trying to take everything out. The second you pick up that crystal, you've got a limited amount of time before the little baddies overtake your defences, so it then becomes a mad dash! You can level up your heroes, equipt them with items to make them stronger, you can heal them using the food you've acquired, or you can have them manage your food/industry systems. The more resources you get, the better modules you will be able to build if you find the right blueprints. Overall the game is a difficult arcade tower-defence mixed with action rpg elements, and a single run through of the alpha took me an hour, becuase i took the time to adventure into every single room. It's a fun game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								   What AMPLITUDE has here are most definitely the makings of a superb game.  The progression of opening doors to begin waves and shape the enemies' overall path is the perfect way to marriage the Tower Defense and Roguelike geres.  "What you'll find behind the door" is just random enough that you can experience "garbage runs", but it's balanced enough that a run is never doomed before it begins.   Risk and reward are balanced very well, too, often in the form of continuous decision making on the player's part: "Do I hunker down in this position, or do I spread out my defenses to guard more resource production?" "Do I pay Dust (resource that lasts only one floor) to a Merchant for items, possibly overextend my resources until I'm done with the floor (and Dust is less precious) or play it safe and make sure I can live to see the next level?"   There may only be three floors to the game as of now, but Dungeon of the Endless is already worth the price of admission if you're a fan of the genres.  And I have no doubt it will only get better from here.
