number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the "crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon, providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival, but it is limited by its supply of "dust", and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.The gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike, tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging, with a bit less of the luck factor of, say, FTL (you'll rarely be thrown into randomly unsurvivable situations) and more strategic decisions to make rather than a roll of the dice. While plotting your route through the dungeon, protecting the crystal is your primary concern. You'll have a range of modules to install in a dungeon, from resource generators to defensive weaponry, and as your power demand starts to exceed supply you'll have to get clever with which parts of the dungeon you keep powered and where you open new doors. Your heroes' abilities and attributes vary widely. Some are slow but powerful tanks, well-suited to holding a static position; others are technically-minded and can operate or repair the modules you build; others still are nimble speedsters ideal for responding to trouble spots or running the crystal to the elevator. Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.The understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated, hand-painted graphics are both surpassingly beautiful, and taken with the game lore (which frequently ties in with that of Amplitude's other titles, Endless Space and Endless Legend) they create a truly unique atmosphere and sense of immersion. The heroes will treat you to some fun banter occasionally, and are great sources of emergent stories. The tale of how you brave robotic swordsman sacrificed himself keeping a horde of nasties from his beloved crystal carrier; or how two of your most dissimilar dungeon explorers form an unstoppable monster-slaying, best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own, which unfold as they ascend the floors with sometimes-shocking outcomes that I won't spoil here. Simply put, the game oozes personality.Whether you're a fan of the genre, or simply someone who appreciates an old-school challenge or a lovingly-made game, I can't recommend Dungeon of the Endless enough. Keep your eyes on Amplitude, because they've just had an amazing year.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												This game is the absolute perfect mix of Tower Defense, Strategy, and RPG, all mixed in with a bit of Beautiful Pixelated Graphics. The Gameplay is Smooth and Entertaining, Resource Management between you and your team is challenging, and Behind every door is the possibility of Life or Death.  This game could easily be played for hours with you and your 3 friends all shuffling around the rooms trying to not Screw up. In this game Teamwork and Communication is crutial and makes the game Entertaining. While you can play Single Player, I highly suggest buying this for you and a friend to play, it is about 10 times more fun with other people.  You have your 4 Resources, Food, Production (Which allows Building Defenses and Production Buildings), Science, And Dust.  Food Allows you to level up, buy items from vendors, heal in the middle of a turn, and even to hire new characters.  Science allows you to Research New Buildings and Building Upgrades, and also to occasionally buy items from vendors although it's more likely to see a vendor buying either Production or Food, And Dust allows you to power rooms for Defenses, Production, and (Most importantly) to stop Monsters from Spawning in a room. The Monsters are pretty Tough to say the least and can make you almost smash your keyboard into the wall which makes resource and power management more crucial to your sanity. To get through a Level you must find the exit and get both your Main Gem and your characters into the Exit Room. This game is Worth the Money and the developers are amazing for this game. If you have the money pick up a few copies for you and your friends

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								After crashing on an unknown planet, Nurse Deena Ratchet and genetically engineered warrior Hikensha began working their way through the ship to hope for an escape. Along the way they recruited a young burglar named Golgy Phurtiver who, incidentally, thinks she's a spider of some sort. Things were going relatively well - Nurse Ratchet discovered a woman in stasis, who was revealed to be a bounty hunter named Sara Numas. They did not know that they were effectively recruiting Hikensha's replacement, however, who died tried to defend another survivor from the alien natives. The party marched upwards, exploring for every resource they could. Another survivor was revived from stasis, but the mercenary (who dubbed himself "Butcher") was eviscerated by what can only presumed to be giant mutant slugs when making casual conversation with a merchant. The three survivors, Deena, Golgy and Sara saved the merchant from the rampaging aliens, and quickly cleaned him out of his wares in exchange for the Dust they were using to power their various defenses, just before they moved on up to a new level of what was beginning to feel like a dungeon. For real though, Dungeon of the Endless does a lot of things right for a... roguelike, resource management 4X, RPG, platypus of a game. And as they're apparently working on multiplayer, I could see this becoming a Thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												I've only put a few hours into this game so far, but it's been great testing the waters and learning how it works. All of the seemingly disparate genre elements are tightly and smartly woven together in a package that seems greater than the sum of its parts. Dense with information at first, you're given a lot of room to learn and grow. There are some random elements at work, but as you learn how the game works you will eventually be able to handle what the game throws at you. Difficult for sure, but not unfair or unmanageable.In addition to the rock-solid gameplay, Dungeon of the Endless is both an aural and visual delight. The soundtrack is excellently paced and fits in with the game incredibly well, and I'm grateful that the soundtrack is included in the game's files already in MP3 format. Graphics are nicely stylized pixel art with some decent lighting and particle effects layered on top. It's always clear to see what's going on and who is who when things get hectic.Dungeon of the Endless also has a nicely balanced sense of dread about what's through every next door, but also a good amount of humor to break up the tension. Not to mention the growing sense of satisfaction and glee as you make it further and further, overcoming steadily greater obstacles. Besides the initial, steep difficulty curve of learning how the game works, each dungeon has a steady - but fair - climb in difficulty as you progress. It's also highly replayable, further adding to the game's value.I'm amazed that the developer even tried to make an RPG/Tower Defense/Roguelike/Strategy hybrid, and even moreso that they actually pulled it off so well. I already know that this is a game I'll be coming back to for years.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												An impressive game from the makers of Endless Legend and Endless Space, the links between the games are clear in the simple resources used in each, and the basic premises the games generally hold, as well as the subtle hints that ALL the games have links with one another that tease their fans; and the enticingly different games of each genre (if you can even define an exact genre for this one!) make their games distinctive and unique, a fresh breeze in genres that are frequently carbon copies of one design or another.Dungeon of the Endless does more than their previous efforts though - this time, it's not just a fresh take on a type of game, they've conjoined multiple genres and come up with something totally different. I would completely recommend it - it's both casually enjoyable, and surprisingly addictive. The simple graphics are not off-putting in the slightest, a testiment to the designers that they were aiming for gameplay far more than scoring 10/10 for being one-up on other developers (and the gorgeous graphics in their other games shows that they can definately deliver on that when they choose to)More than that though, they master the roguelike genre by giving you multiple unlockable bonuses for replaying, as well as gradually building your ability with the game; but not to a point where a seasoned, experienced player would always score FAR better than a new starter to it, so long as the new starter was prepared to learn from them.It's also fantastic for multiplayer, far more than many of the type, and the multiplayer is a totally different experience, one I'd recommend for anyone - though they may want to wait for the next release before doing it seriously with other people (save and load for multiplayer, bug-fixes, etc) - but I'd hasten to add that the solo play is hardly lacking either.Even when you think you've compeltely mastered an approach, a run of bad luck can leave you in a seriously dangerous position; and if the standard play begins to bore, switching the capsule type or the characters you play with totally changes how the game plays. A big thumbs up from me, and it further increases the respect I have for Ampitude's games as a whole.One last mention - they also have a quirky humour that's entirely their own, whether it comes to the fake latin-esque drugs on the infirmary pod to the in-game item descriptions and names; or simply in the tiny hints about their games and the secrets in them; or even in the lift conversations that unlock secrets in character biographies; all the hints and text are small and subtle, not requiring you to be involved; but if you want to put in the time to seek out their secrets, it's a satisfying reward for it too.A big congratulations from an experienced gamer to the developers - it's a lovely piece of work and makes me excited to see their next!

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's alpha as all hell, the skill system needs to be implemented STAT, and there needs to be more variety to the core gameplay. While I understand that there needs to be a final, kill all failure (losing all dust), but make that a secondary worry, with the first being character survival and exploration. I say this mainly because I shouldn't need to step through a door, and have an inane worry of enemies flooding towards the crystal. That should be, if anything, a worst case scenario. While speaking of the crystal, implement more ways to obtain dust than unknowingly entering a room with a dust supply. It's a good thing this game is in bare-bones alpha, and still has much too look forward to. However, these are all minor complaints that WILL be filtered out or diverted in Dungeon's slow alpha-to-beta building process. The game already is good for just playing and relaxing. It doesn't require so much focus, you can't have other things at hand/in mind. Furthermore, I feel the game leaves plenty of room for an engaging story and style. People who played/enjoyed Endless Space, or more specifically, its lore will find this game intriguing enough. Perhaps wait 'til beta? I recommend it anyway but, don't jump on this bandwagon if you aren't planning on giving it time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												A charming party roguelike and tower defence mashup. The basic idea is exploring rooms, protecting your generator from incoming mobs and then carrying your generator through the maze to the next level before the mobs get you. Works well. There's also manufacturing the resources familiar from Endless Space, but very simple. It can be harshly random in the manner roguelikes tend to be, but the game provides easy starting difficulties to compensate. For the replayability there's unlockable characters and game modes (landing pods).I can't resist making comparisons with SotS: The Pit even though these are fairly different games, The Pit being pure Roguelike. Both are still games with similar theme set in same respective universes as previous 4X space strategy games. Specifically, the different approach to the lore interests me. SotS has well constructed universe that is often explained with lots of text. Endless seems more haphazardly build, focusing more on overall feel rather than details. Filling in the blanks is left to the player if he wants them filled. I would say SotS is more like a novel while Endless is more like a painting of a landscape or and instrumental piece of music.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's a strange hybrid of roguelike and tower defense, where you open doors to reveal unpowered rooms (and sometimes merchants, chests, caches of resources, new heroes, or monsters). You can power the rooms up, allowing modules (essentially towers and resource generators) to be built inside of them, and preventing monsters from spawning inside of them. Every time a door is opened, you receive your allotment of resources per door opened (depending on your generators) and there is a chance that waves of monsters will spawn from the unpowered rooms, who will attempt to attack your core.Upon finding the exit to the next floor, you must have a hero carry the core to the exit, each room you pass through losing power as it is disconnected from the core, with monsters spawning non-stop from unpowered rooms.It's a pretty unique game, and despite balance issues (hopefully due to the game's incomplete beta state), is quite fun. 4-player co-op is up soon on their roadmap, so it'll be interesting to see how that works, or if it'll be a hot mess with people accidentally opening multiple doors at once due to poor coordination and getting everyone killed.Also, it's worth noting that the developer has handled this game's early access in an extremely professional manner, and that development has sped along at a steady clip.

Early Access Review
								(As of 0.1.1)It’s tough, and probably needs a little rebalancing as to where things spawn and how much, but being it's in alpha I'm extremely impressed. I made it through on my 5th or 6th try, at least as far as the early access would allow (level 4 I think?). I can tell I'm going to love this game though. The two negative things I have to say about it are that occasionally it'll seem a bit unfair and loot will only rarely spawn that you can use if you don’t have a diverse team (something you can't choose). Once I started a new game died after I opened the third door. There was nothing that I could have done to prevent this and was a clear case of the game killing me instead of me dying. Many times, starting out, you'll find that any gear you stumble across is only good to be sold since neither of your two people can use a pistol, for example  (despite one of them being able to use machine guns...?). Whether the latter issue is problem with the loot drops or the gear system is subjective I suppose.All that being said though, I love this game so far. I love the genre bending mechanics and the not-quite-shadowrun and not-quite-fallout world. I love the art and sound. I love the droplets of story you get with each random party and each piece of gear you stumble across. I cannot recommend this game enough.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												If you like FTL you'll like this game.  It has elements of a lot of different types of games:  4x, Rogue-like, Tower Defense, etc.    The goal is to escape the dungeon floor by floor.    Each floor starts the same way, you and a power source.    You need to explore until you find the exit.   Then you need to plan a way to move the power source to the exit.   Moving said power source spawns a neverending slew of monsters.   Monsters spawn from unpowered areas so you can set up an escape route.   All the while you need to balance leveling your team (Food), researching modules (Science) and building defenses or resource generating modules.   I'm 0 for 7 on "Too Easy" so expect a challenge.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								One more door. Just one more door.I am not a huge fan of tower defense games, but this little rogue-like has me hooked. Beyond the simple build-and-defend mechanic at the heart of every TD, DotE adds a compelling risk-reward element in the choice between doubling down and heading to the exit with the resources you've collected, or opening one more door in hopes of finding treasure or an ally at the risk of multiple waves of enemies threatening to destroy everything you have built. Striking that balance is key to your survival.Dungeon of the Endless is still in its early stages, but this little monster has a lot of potential. More items, more enemies, more levels, more non-combat encounters, story elements, heroic side quests, and party management mechanics are sure to come, but I would love to see competing parties of survivors taking resources (multiplayer plix?), the ability to relock doors (albeit either as limited use item or heroic ability), and different environments (with more incredible music added to what is already a killer soundtrack).I cannot wait to see how this game develops. I am officially pumped.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												I first played this game in Early Access, and discarded it pretty quickly. The balance was off, it felt too restrictive, and didn't really offer me anything fun. I ditched it fast.But I've just installed the release version, and now I'm suitably impressed.The game operates on the idea that each door you open represents a "turn", a turn where heroes are healed, resources gained, technology researched, and cooldowns ticked. During that turn you might fight monsters, open chests, find merchants, stuff like that. Your main ways of influencing the game aren't to physically control the characters while they fight, it's to position the characters in rooms such that they do the most damage. Or pop their abilities at the right time, swap their equipment, or change which rooms have electricity going to them (and consequently, have light/defenses/resource collection).Unlike normal RPGs - there is no gold and no experience points. There are four resources; food, industry, science, and dust. You level your heroes up with food, build turrets/resource gatherers with industry, research new technology with science, and power rooms with dust. Each of these resources is crucial in it's own way, and the management of those resources defines if you win or not.Because there's no gold or XP, this game really feels different. The incentive structure is completely unique; you don't want to fight enemies, you need to open doors. But opening doors might get too dangerous once you get near the end of a floor, and it might be better to skip it and run. You might spend food on levelling up, or healing your people. There's no global currency, merchants accept a random resource as currency in trade, and each resource gets used every floor, so you never hoard anything.The coop is fun, but it also really needs fixes. You cannot save coop games, so you have to be prepared to stick it out for the 2+ hours required to play a round - or abandon the game. Players cannot share items between them (but they can share resources), they need to sell items at the merchant and have the other player buy it - at a loss. Random crashes and freezes during level load completely take down a lobby (which means you need to start an entirely new game, see the "no saving" above). And there is no character sharing. So if your friend's only character dies, and you're left alone with two characters, you can't share it with him. You might as well start over, or wait until a new character appears in a floor. Characters that aren't controlled by you don't get unlocked in your game. So if your friend took a character you haven't unlocked, and plays the game until that character is unlocked for him, you won't get the unlock. *You* have to play the character (probably in singleplayer) to unlock them. Overall the bugs aren't too noticeable. And it's a neat game that took all the usual formulaic elements of a game and twisted them slightly to make a totally new sort of game, without getting too abstract or weird about it.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
Early Access Review
								Dungeon of the Endless is a blast. A unique spin on the rogue-like genre, I found myself pretty additcted from the start. I'm a fan of rogue-likes in general as well as tower defense games and this one is by far the best merges of the two I have seen. I've already beaten the Alpha but I will say that I cant wait for future updates to try this again.Overall, the game is extremely polished for an Alpha and I encountered no bugs so far, having played multiple sessions. The UI is clean and intuitive, and looks good overall. Its clear this is an Alpha but only because there are a few areas marked in the UI where functionality is going to be added. This game is smoother and more polished than some full games I've played, though it is a pixel game and I do have a powerhouse PC so that may be a factor. The game ran smooth and areas that arent complete are clearly marked and unintrusive.As far as the difficulty and learning curve, this game nailed it. It starts off fairly easy and simple, quickly becoming more complex and strategic as you progress to further depths and the maps become bigger. The tower defense aspects that werent necessary at the start became more important later on as you start to be overwhelmed on multiple angles. The game eventually developed into a risk-reward game for me because I found the exit but there were tons of unopened rooms for me to still explore. My only complaint would be that eventually I had tons of industry with nothing to use it on and it just piled up.In the end, this game is a deffinite buy for anyone remotely interested. Looking forward to playing more devs, keep up the good work!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the "crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon, providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival, but it is limited by its supply of "dust", and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.The gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike, tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging, with a bit less of the luck factor of, say, FTL (you'll rarely be thrown into randomly unsurvivable situations) and more strategic decisions to make rather than a roll of the dice. While plotting your route through the dungeon, protecting the crystal is your primary concern. You'll have a range of modules to install in a dungeon, from resource generators to defensive weaponry, and as your power demand starts to exceed supply you'll have to get clever with which parts of the dungeon you keep powered and where you open new doors. Your heroes' abilities and attributes vary widely. Some are slow but powerful tanks, well-suited to holding a static position; others are technically-minded and can operate or repair the modules you build; others still are nimble speedsters ideal for responding to trouble spots or running the crystal to the elevator. Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.The understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated, hand-painted graphics are both surpassingly beautiful, and taken with the game lore (which frequently ties in with that of Amplitude's other titles, Endless Space and Endless Legend) they create a truly unique atmosphere and sense of immersion. The heroes will treat you to some fun banter occasionally, and are great sources of emergent stories. The tale of how you brave robotic swordsman sacrificed himself keeping a horde of nasties from his beloved crystal carrier; or how two of your most dissimilar dungeon explorers form an unstoppable monster-slaying, best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own, which unfold as they ascend the floors with sometimes-shocking outcomes that I won't spoil here. Simply put, the game oozes personality.Whether you're a fan of the genre, or simply someone who appreciates an old-school challenge or a lovingly-made game, I can't recommend Dungeon of the Endless enough. Keep your eyes on Amplitude, because they've just had an amazing year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								There isn't much that hasn't already been said about this game. It really is as good as it sounds. And it is amazingly addictive; be prepared to find yourself sucked in for hours at a time if you're a fan of tower defense or strategy games in general. I've never been big on the tower defense formula for its own sake, but DotE sold me on the idea that tower defense can be fun. Of course, DotE offers much more than just tower defense; it introduces an economy-like system--if you've ever played a 4x strategy game, the system will look pretty familiar--that ties in with the tower defense setup (among other things) and at the same time rewards you for exploration and taking calculated risks, which is what the game is really about. On top of that, the game gives you a specific resource that can be used to power unlocked rooms and the defenses and production modules you've built in them but also doubles as currency; deciding to use it for currency instead of power always has consequences. If you like a challenge--the kind that requires a brain--Dungeon of the Endless will hook you pretty fast.The RPG elements add a surprising amount of depth to gameplay. You may not fall in love with any of the characters that make up your party, but you WILL be dismayed when you lose one, especially if you've spent any amount of time getting them kitted up--aside from the sinking realization that you now have one less defender. With different skillsets and weapon types, recruiting and keeping characters alive is an investment in your team-building strategy as different characters can complement each other in different ways (melee with ranged, for instance) and can also be put to work boosting specific segments of your economy to differing degrees depending on a proficiency statistic. Future releases promise even more layers to team-building, as inter-character relationship balancing (guards vs. inmates) and personalities will also play a role in pursuing (or avoiding) character combinations. Granted, the alpha is very short and misses out on giving you the chance to bring any long-term team-building strategies into play, and especially early-on you'll find yourself taking any character you come across just to keep your team's collective head above water. Having a really good team fall into place is more a matter of luck than planning. Hopefully later versions will realize the potential there.New players should be aware of just how short the game currently is. Dungeon of the *Endless* isn't really (endless, that is). Not yet. At only three levels it's a bit of a tease, one that lasts about an hour and a half even with obsessive exploration of every nook and cranny. I can hardly fault the developers though. They've told us what we'll find going in. The randomization of the levels (and recruitable character encounters) and the way the game still manages to throw curve-balls and stay challenging keeps me playing and giddily anticipating the masterpiece that this game will be if the developers deliver. The alpha is already amazing. I doubt we'll be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												An endless journey from the depths of un-knowing cluster♥♥♥♥, to the peaks of 500-industry-a-floor victory. Dungeon of the Endless may fulfill a multitude of gaming genres, but in my opinion, it satisfies most in the learning curve, and the utter feeling of good, earned, whole-hearted progress. Your first time through will see you lose a few runs, then manage to get to level 11, then finally complete the game on Too Easy, patting yourself on the back thoroughly, having unlocked a few achievements. Are you finished? Alas, you are not. You look at your character list;"♥♥♥♥in L m8 so many damn characters tah ♥♥♥♥in jack around wit"And then you notice how badass Hakenshi looks, and then you realize how broken Lady Jolari is, and you see all of the ships and achievements you can unlock, and you're like;"Hot diggity doggy I'mma get me some achievements"So you end up spending a full day playing multiplayer, leaving your friends behind on floors for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, until finally, at last, you finish a run on the Medbay, because no one knows how to manage food resources. I came here for the pixel art and the soundtrack, both of which are absolutely marvelous. The gameplay in singleplayer far exceeds the multiplayer; the amount of control and strategy you'll slowly learn to control is incredibly rewarding; your first playthrough will have floor clears of around 15 minutes each, but by the time you get going, you can finish them in under 2 minutes (I've managed to get 59 seconds in a multiplayer Floor 3). 10/10 Graphics10/10 Audio10/10 Expectations10/10 Singleplayer8/10 Multiplayer (poorly optimized for shared resources, but not a huge issue)baller amount of characters yo and the DLC is ripe for pickin, though, Crystal Edition is a little pricey for what you get.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												PROS-Diverse cast of misfits that you will lead to an inevitable demise.-Creates a wonderfully haunting sense of isolation through both the visual art style and the excellent soundtrack.-Somehow manages to blend tower defence, rts, rpg and roguelike elements together without failing at any of them.-Easy mode will ruthlessly murder your squad over and over again. -Different types of escape pods to unlock, each modifying how the game is played.-Pixellated pugs.NEUTRALS-This is definitely a roguelike, and sometimes you'll do as much as you can and still fail. Sometimes you will find the exit to the next floor in seven or eight rooms, sometimes it will be the last door on the floor. I find that being stretched thin and having to guard three fronts with a handful of turrets and heroes to be half the fun.CONS-An essential tactic for later in the game involves using heores in unpowered rooms in order to prevent enemy spawns. I'm not sure if this is mentioned anywhere in-game. I found out about it on the forums.I can't recommend this strongly enough. If you're a fan of any of the genres listed on the tags, do yourself a favour and pick this up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												The best implementation of a co-op Roguelike that I've seen. It mixes turn-based elements and real-time play, so that it's not one constant unbroken action sequence - you get downtime after each room unless you get overrun. The premise is simple: Open doors to explore the level, and beware of enemy spawns in unpowered rooms after you open each door. Find the exit, and carry your crystal from the entry point to it - but as soon as you pick it up, monsters will spawn until you escape.The lowest difficulty mode is tough, but reasonable - and there's one more above that if you're looking for a serious challenge. The descriptions of the items are humorous, the game is easy to understand, and offers a good challenge without being punishing. And it's fun on your own, but even moreso with up to three friends you can collaborate with. Highly recommended if you like Roguelikes and want to get your friends in on the action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
What do I rate it? A significantly high 7/10.Why?In brief; it's an amazing dungeon crawler with a tower-defense aspect seamlessly and cleverly incorporated into the fighting aspect of the game between each round of opening a new random door. You could trawl the floors for hours and spend even longer over-thinking your strategic moves between rooms. After the fourth or fifth floor, you begin to feel a familiarity building and the game slowly becomes a little repetitive. Discovering the same rooms you did two floors ago - like a treasure room, banquet surprise (food bonus), scrap parts (factory parts) and yadda yadda. So although the maps are all unique and no path is the same as the last map, you begin to build a familiarity with the small number of different custom rooms you could venture into, which to an extent, makes you feel like there's nothing new to discover and you've seen everything already. Just in a different order between the floors you take.Multiplayer is nonexistent online. I've tried searching for public matches and to no avail found any. So the multiplayer aspect would only be feesible if you had friends who also the game to play with and don't mind spending a vast amount of time on a playthrough that you can't save or return too. As of yet anyway. Overall...?Yes. It's a game that will entertain you for hours if you enjoy dungeon crawlers. Do not buy for the mulitplayer aspect, unless someone else owns the game and can be relied upon to play with you for hours at a time to even attempt to finish a playthrough. Atmospherics, music and gameplay is fairly good. Overal; buy this game when it's on sale. I wouldn't say it's worth the retail mark-up and it definitely needs a lot of rough edges smoothing out. Such as bugs and incomplete fixes. But a very promising arcade style game.

content:

Early Access Review
								I picked up this game when it was back in Early Alpha, and at the time it felt a bit feature-scant. However, they have since gone into Beta, and I can safely say that this is worth every cent.DotE is best summarized as a mix between a roguelike, turn-based strategy game, and a sort of tower defense. Your goal is to open doors in the dungeon so that you can find the exit and then you have to carry your power source (a crystal) to that exit without it getting destroyed by the various monsters that inhabit the dungeon. The learning curve is a bit steep at first, but once you figure out how everything works, this game becomes incredibly fun.There are some drawbacks, such as the technical glitches, occasional crashes (at least for me), and some balance issues, but the devs are highly involved in the community and are taking steps to actively address these issues - more than I can say for other Early Access games.You can find yourself sinking a lot of time into this game if you take the time to enjoy it. I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								(As of version Alpha 0.2.1) I picked up this game on a whim - it had the specs: indie, sci-fi, strategy, and fun art-direction.When I first picked it up, only the bare mechanics were in place. You took your heroes from room to room and tried to fight back the hordes going after your crystal. It was compelling then and with the features they continue to add, the game keeps getting more addictive. The idea is that a prison space ship crashes on an unknown planet. You need to direct your 'heroes' (guards and/or prisoners) to find the exit of the dungeon that they're stuck in. Each room will have doors. Every time you open a door you discover a new room which may have an item, a resource, or monsters. As you open more doors, you collect resourses and power which you can use to power/light-up rooms. Monsters will not appear in powered rooms while they could potentially show up in un-powered rooms. There are two phases to each level. The first phase is strategic exploration and tower defence: you can install turrets in your powered rooms to help your heroes fight the monsters. The second phase requires you to bring your crystal to the exit. It's a bit of a mad dash to the finish line. As you leave a room with the crystal, that room loses it's power supply. The two phases keep the levels fresh and keeps you planning ahead. If you enjoy strategy games, tower defence games, sci-fi, indie, elements of RPG, or like good pixel art then this game is for you! Even better, as they're still developing the game, more an more features are being added!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								   What AMPLITUDE has here are most definitely the makings of a superb game.  The progression of opening doors to begin waves and shape the enemies' overall path is the perfect way to marriage the Tower Defense and Roguelike geres.  "What you'll find behind the door" is just random enough that you can experience "garbage runs", but it's balanced enough that a run is never doomed before it begins.   Risk and reward are balanced very well, too, often in the form of continuous decision making on the player's part: "Do I hunker down in this position, or do I spread out my defenses to guard more resource production?" "Do I pay Dust (resource that lasts only one floor) to a Merchant for items, possibly overextend my resources until I'm done with the floor (and Dust is less precious) or play it safe and make sure I can live to see the next level?"   There may only be three floors to the game as of now, but Dungeon of the Endless is already worth the price of admission if you're a fan of the genres.  And I have no doubt it will only get better from here.

I got this game at 50% during some sale and worried a bit about buying it on impulse (yes, 10 bucks is some money for me, and yes I  went for the Crystal Edition). I can now see those fears where unfounded since it's worth each and every cent I payed for it, and IMO, even more.Almost two years have passed since I bought it and I sitll ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												This is a game that tries to mix some unusual set of mechanics into one game. I used to play this during early access and I could see the potential back then but it was far from balanced; it had one particular winning strategy that rendered most of the mechanisms in the game pointless.I'm happy to say that these days are long gone, the final version of Dungeon of the Endless is a very successful experimentation in game design that will keep you entertained exploring different strategies you never thought you'd use together in the same game.There's a lot of luck involved though, keep that in mind if that's not your thing. But luck is a factor in many games considered good, specially in rogue-likes. In these games the fun is like a good game of cards, you develop skills as you play the game over and over again until you know the best strategies for the hand you were given. And there are many cards and possibilities in Dungeon of the Endless. I totally recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the "crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon, providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival, but it is limited by its supply of "dust", and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.The gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike, tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging, with a bit less of the luck factor of, say, FTL (you'll rarely be thrown into randomly unsurvivable situations) and more strategic decisions to make rather than a roll of the dice. While plotting your route through the dungeon, protecting the crystal is your primary concern. You'll have a range of modules to install in a dungeon, from resource generators to defensive weaponry, and as your power demand starts to exceed supply you'll have to get clever with which parts of the dungeon you keep powered and where you open new doors. Your heroes' abilities and attributes vary widely. Some are slow but powerful tanks, well-suited to holding a static position; others are technically-minded and can operate or repair the modules you build; others still are nimble speedsters ideal for responding to trouble spots or running the crystal to the elevator. Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.The understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated, hand-painted graphics are both surpassingly beautiful, and taken with the game lore (which frequently ties in with that of Amplitude's other titles, Endless Space and Endless Legend) they create a truly unique atmosphere and sense of immersion. The heroes will treat you to some fun banter occasionally, and are great sources of emergent stories. The tale of how you brave robotic swordsman sacrificed himself keeping a horde of nasties from his beloved crystal carrier; or how two of your most dissimilar dungeon explorers form an unstoppable monster-slaying, best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own, which unfold as they ascend the floors with sometimes-shocking outcomes that I won't spoil here. Simply put, the game oozes personality.Whether you're a fan of the genre, or simply someone who appreciates an old-school challenge or a lovingly-made game, I can't recommend Dungeon of the Endless enough. Keep your eyes on Amplitude, because they've just had an amazing year.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless has brought me back to my gaming roots from the early 90s, yet pulled me through a world of fresh new elements I haven't quite expreience fully.First, you crash land on a planet, and are plunged deep into the dungeon. You find yourself in a room with one other and a crystal. As you manage your way through the first floor you encounter monsters of various traits, merchants with certain goods, and science machines to advance yourself. Leveling up is achieved through the gaining of the food resource, and you can manufacture food, and 2 others. Once your reach the exit, you must bring your crystal with you and be challenged by al the monsters of the floor.I find after a few play throughs that DotE is a perfect game. Nothing more needs to be added to this little masterpiece, and nothing needs to be taken away. Well balanced, well designed, and a tough play, like games used to be!I challenge anyone new to this game to attempt to take this game on on easy mode.  Be prepared a force feeding of humility!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								TL;DR Great game, devoted devs, buy now if you want to shape the game and experience the development.As of 0.6.1 i am enjoying this game thoroughly. There are enough characters and since adding 8 levels an indepth clear is currently around 3 hours of play. Though i have read aot of complaints and they fall into two categories too hard or no diversity. In respect to difficulty there are currently two options, easy and too easy. As their name suggests  neither option is very difficult. However if you play this game and do not consider that is a combinations of many game types and aproach it as one you will lose fairly quickly. Also, aproaching each level with no forethought or strategy will cause a loss aswell. It is of course a strategy game so those who lack it will not suceed. Furthermore, the learning curve is fairly easy and once you get the hang of it is a blast.In respect to a lack of diversity you have to remember this game is still in alpha. if you are buying a early access game looking for a full game experience then you will be dissapointed. The devs are pushing out consistent updates, much faster than alot of the other early access games on steam. They fix bugs very quickly and if a patch is game breaking they pull it so you can still play while they work on it. By buying the game now you can shape development by voting on their website.The game itself is quite simple. There are currently 3 resources industry, science and food. Industry is for building modules and major modules help produce those three resources. Minor modules are turrets support turrets and defensive turrets. Science allows you to resource upgrades for your modules and new modules themselves. food allows you to recruit new heroes after your starting heroes, level up your heores(current max lvl 8 due to 8 Floors) and heal them during fights.You use these resources to build a defense network so that when the exit of the lvl is found you can safely bring your crystal(the object that allows you to power rooms so you can build in them) to the next lvl. Each level gets increasingly difficult with new enemies and more rooms.Heroes: Heroes come in all shapes in sizes and currently there are four stats, and five weapons types(currently 0.6.1). Stats are health,speed,damage and wit. Weapon types are sword, spear, pistol, machine gun, unarmed. health is how much life you start with and how much life you get every time you level up. Speed is movement speed. Wit is comparable to an intelligence stat but is mostly used for heroes you can operate major modules(Operating is to give a bonus to their production rate or bonus it gives) by increasing the operator bonus. Damage is the amount of damage you do. All of these stats scale when you level the heroe and different heroes are more proficient in different stats.There is no heroe that is useless all of them serve a specific purpose and you can win by using any combination of them.Also, there are armors and support items, most with comical names or premises. Finally a great amount of thought has gone into this game from the item descriptions and the heroe backgrounds to the strategies that are available and to the details in each room. This ia a great product and i am highly anticipating the finished version.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												TL;DR || The game is a fun mix of dungeon crawling RPG and tower defense. Perma-death, random dungeon layouts, and a good selection of characters add to the replay value. Multiple heroes to unlock. Level 'em up. Gear 'em up. Meet new heroes while in the dungeon and have them join your party. Find ancient treasure. Research new tech. Die, lose it all, and happily start over again. The devs are a pretty swell bunch too!!!I think the art style is fantastic, and the same can be said for the sound design and soundtrack. The gameplay is quite fluid with a nice interface and can also be quite challenging with a good bit a strategy mixed in. Clear the dungeon room by room using your heroes, while setting up defenses to protect your ship's power core. Once you find the floor's exit, defend one of your heroes as he slowly carries the core to the elevator. You can power up rooms to prevent enemies from spawning in them and use that power to set up turrets and resource nodes; this helps you create a defensible path to the elevator, because once you touch that core, they don't stop coming.The developers are worth mentioning too. AMPLITUDE is hands down one of my favorite studios. They put out quality products and continue to provide support for their games beyond their initial release.If you'd like to see a bit of gameplay:


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												This game is the absolute perfect mix of Tower Defense, Strategy, and RPG, all mixed in with a bit of Beautiful Pixelated Graphics. The Gameplay is Smooth and Entertaining, Resource Management between you and your team is challenging, and Behind every door is the possibility of Life or Death.  This game could easily be played for hours with you and your 3 friends all shuffling around the rooms trying to not Screw up. In this game Teamwork and Communication is crutial and makes the game Entertaining. While you can play Single Player, I highly suggest buying this for you and a friend to play, it is about 10 times more fun with other people.  You have your 4 Resources, Food, Production (Which allows Building Defenses and Production Buildings), Science, And Dust.  Food Allows you to level up, buy items from vendors, heal in the middle of a turn, and even to hire new characters.  Science allows you to Research New Buildings and Building Upgrades, and also to occasionally buy items from vendors although it's more likely to see a vendor buying either Production or Food, And Dust allows you to power rooms for Defenses, Production, and (Most importantly) to stop Monsters from Spawning in a room. The Monsters are pretty Tough to say the least and can make you almost smash your keyboard into the wall which makes resource and power management more crucial to your sanity. To get through a Level you must find the exit and get both your Main Gem and your characters into the Exit Room. This game is Worth the Money and the developers are amazing for this game. If you have the money pick up a few copies for you and your friends

								if you are anything like me, then you get a very queesy feeling whenever you see the "early access game" hovering over a game's store page. it signifies many crushed hopes, and a lot of "potential" meaning the game COULD be a lot of fun, but right now, it's an empty experience, lacking features, mechanics and content.HOWEVER i was totally BLOWN away with this game, which didn't show a single frayed edge. it has stellar music, fantastic visuals, and some really novel and innovative mechanics, taking both the tower defense genre, and the rogue-like genre to places we've never seen before.everything in it is already fun, and feels complete, which means it can only mean the game will get better! we hope. after being able to play this game on a shared account i am seriously considering splerging for the founder pack. 15 feels like a good price for this game as it is another game which may show many unique experiences, and therefore, many hours of play. i like everything Amplitude is doing with this game, and look forward to see what direction they take it in.

Posted: July 13, 2015
												I really enjoy this game, the art style is beautiful and the gameplay hooks you in but i think the singleplayer is hard to manage. I think that the pixelated top down format works well for managing all your heroes when trying to survive the hordes of monsters swarming from unpowered rooms. The building and research systems keep you on your toes when an example would be you are forced to choose whether to buy more prods to keep away badies or get an industry generator to help you later on. The only thing that I have managed to dislike about this game is the single player, trying to order around 2-4 heroes on your own while building defense turrets, healing the heroes,and using their power ups can get overwhelming and complicated especially if you are not used to the controls. Overall this game is a brilliant game with an amazing art style, great upgrading and building systems. even though the single player is hard to manage it is fun getting frustrated at Dungeon of the Endless.

Posted: October 14, 2016
												    Holy Crap THIS is one of the best games I've played in a long time. A great mix of RPG and Tower Defense! The UI is great, the game mechanics are good, and I love the humor you can get out of the dialogue on the elevator. With the different ships, there are different game modes, which I find quite diverse. Unique characters have a bit backstory, which is a great departure from the RPG storyless characters I've seen on other games.    I have very few complaints about this game: 1) The "Too Easy" and "Easy" modes probably should be renamed to normal and hard. Simply for the fact that on "Too Easy", I found it challenging, but enjoyable. Unfortunately on "Easy", can never get past the 4th floor. Even if the idea of the difficulty names are for humor, (which I did have a good laugh) it can be missleading for others whom might take this game much more seriously.     Overall, I found this game to be VERY replayable. Not many games do that for me. (GTA Series, Red Dead Redemption, etc) With many characters to mix and the many ship choices, this game IS in my top 10 favorite games to play :D

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the "crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon, providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival, but it is limited by its supply of "dust", and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.The gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike, tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging, with a bit less of the luck factor of, say, FTL (you'll rarely be thrown into randomly unsurvivable situations) and more strategic decisions to make rather than a roll of the dice. While plotting your route through the dungeon, protecting the crystal is your primary concern. You'll have a range of modules to install in a dungeon, from resource generators to defensive weaponry, and as your power demand starts to exceed supply you'll have to get clever with which parts of the dungeon you keep powered and where you open new doors. Your heroes' abilities and attributes vary widely. Some are slow but powerful tanks, well-suited to holding a static position; others are technically-minded and can operate or repair the modules you build; others still are nimble speedsters ideal for responding to trouble spots or running the crystal to the elevator. Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.The understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated, hand-painted graphics are both surpassingly beautiful, and taken with the game lore (which frequently ties in with that of Amplitude's other titles, Endless Space and Endless Legend) they create a truly unique atmosphere and sense of immersion. The heroes will treat you to some fun banter occasionally, and are great sources of emergent stories. The tale of how you brave robotic swordsman sacrificed himself keeping a horde of nasties from his beloved crystal carrier; or how two of your most dissimilar dungeon explorers form an unstoppable monster-slaying, best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own, which unfold as they ascend the floors with sometimes-shocking outcomes that I won't spoil here. Simply put, the game oozes personality.Whether you're a fan of the genre, or simply someone who appreciates an old-school challenge or a lovingly-made game, I can't recommend Dungeon of the Endless enough. Keep your eyes on Amplitude, because they've just had an amazing year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								There isn't much that hasn't already been said about this game. It really is as good as it sounds. And it is amazingly addictive; be prepared to find yourself sucked in for hours at a time if you're a fan of tower defense or strategy games in general. I've never been big on the tower defense formula for its own sake, but DotE sold me on the idea that tower defense can be fun. Of course, DotE offers much more than just tower defense; it introduces an economy-like system--if you've ever played a 4x strategy game, the system will look pretty familiar--that ties in with the tower defense setup (among other things) and at the same time rewards you for exploration and taking calculated risks, which is what the game is really about. On top of that, the game gives you a specific resource that can be used to power unlocked rooms and the defenses and production modules you've built in them but also doubles as currency; deciding to use it for currency instead of power always has consequences. If you like a challenge--the kind that requires a brain--Dungeon of the Endless will hook you pretty fast.The RPG elements add a surprising amount of depth to gameplay. You may not fall in love with any of the characters that make up your party, but you WILL be dismayed when you lose one, especially if you've spent any amount of time getting them kitted up--aside from the sinking realization that you now have one less defender. With different skillsets and weapon types, recruiting and keeping characters alive is an investment in your team-building strategy as different characters can complement each other in different ways (melee with ranged, for instance) and can also be put to work boosting specific segments of your economy to differing degrees depending on a proficiency statistic. Future releases promise even more layers to team-building, as inter-character relationship balancing (guards vs. inmates) and personalities will also play a role in pursuing (or avoiding) character combinations. Granted, the alpha is very short and misses out on giving you the chance to bring any long-term team-building strategies into play, and especially early-on you'll find yourself taking any character you come across just to keep your team's collective head above water. Having a really good team fall into place is more a matter of luck than planning. Hopefully later versions will realize the potential there.New players should be aware of just how short the game currently is. Dungeon of the *Endless* isn't really (endless, that is). Not yet. At only three levels it's a bit of a tease, one that lasts about an hour and a half even with obsessive exploration of every nook and cranny. I can hardly fault the developers though. They've told us what we'll find going in. The randomization of the levels (and recruitable character encounters) and the way the game still manages to throw curve-balls and stay challenging keeps me playing and giddily anticipating the masterpiece that this game will be if the developers deliver. The alpha is already amazing. I doubt we'll be disappointed.

Early Access Review
								Well I had my first taste of it, I think this game is really fun. I was wanting a Tower Defense type of game...but wanted to find something that had other elements if possible. Well I randomly came across this and I liked the art style instantly...Few games actually interest me with the oldish pixel style but this sure did. Its pretty fun overall, my first playthrough I expected to get killed while learning the game but it is EXTREMELY easy to pick up and play instantly. I made it from start to exit and fully explored the first 3 levels and finally parished on level 4 as waves got quite a bit larger. Its fun, its not too easy or too hard. Theres items, abilities, and the ability to level up and heal your heros. Theres artifacts to research more tech which I love, theres multiple different resources to take advantage of in multiple ways...its just a fun game. So far I cant say too much bad about this title as I was craving a certain game, I saw this and got more than expected..nothing more, nothing less. Very Fun, and im happy this is only in Alpha, the good can only get better from here. I recommend this game if it is below $10 any day. gameplay, graphics(if the style appeals to you and it does to me), and randomly generated dungeons for extra replay value that could be limitless depending how much you like the game.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												An endless journey from the depths of un-knowing cluster♥♥♥♥, to the peaks of 500-industry-a-floor victory. Dungeon of the Endless may fulfill a multitude of gaming genres, but in my opinion, it satisfies most in the learning curve, and the utter feeling of good, earned, whole-hearted progress. Your first time through will see you lose a few runs, then manage to get to level 11, then finally complete the game on Too Easy, patting yourself on the back thoroughly, having unlocked a few achievements. Are you finished? Alas, you are not. You look at your character list;"♥♥♥♥in L m8 so many damn characters tah ♥♥♥♥in jack around wit"And then you notice how badass Hakenshi looks, and then you realize how broken Lady Jolari is, and you see all of the ships and achievements you can unlock, and you're like;"Hot diggity doggy I'mma get me some achievements"So you end up spending a full day playing multiplayer, leaving your friends behind on floors for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, until finally, at last, you finish a run on the Medbay, because no one knows how to manage food resources. I came here for the pixel art and the soundtrack, both of which are absolutely marvelous. The gameplay in singleplayer far exceeds the multiplayer; the amount of control and strategy you'll slowly learn to control is incredibly rewarding; your first playthrough will have floor clears of around 15 minutes each, but by the time you get going, you can finish them in under 2 minutes (I've managed to get 59 seconds in a multiplayer Floor 3). 10/10 Graphics10/10 Audio10/10 Expectations10/10 Singleplayer8/10 Multiplayer (poorly optimized for shared resources, but not a huge issue)baller amount of characters yo and the DLC is ripe for pickin, though, Crystal Edition is a little pricey for what you get.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												Take FTL style micro and put it into a rogue-lite (or rogue-like or whatever you want to call it,) game with tower defense elements and you get Dungeon of the Endless. Pick two heroes and a game modifier (the type of pod you crash into the dungeon in) and you can recruit an additional two heroes for a maximum of four (if your original two survive) characters with special powers that can level up and equip with items. You get resources by building generators for Industry, Science, and Food and protect them with a host of 'modules' you research throughout a dungeon. (and personal interactions in single player depending if you have two specific characters.) I bought the game on sale and the multiplayer was broken for about 3 weeks until they released a new update but now it seems to be working well for most people. So I guess keep in mind the game studio developing this game is busy with all the other games they are working on at the same time, multiplayer tends to still have an occasional bug. The multiplayer is fun but you need good communication at the end to succeed. Also if you happen to play the game please know this game seems to be taking the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of FTL by stepping up their naming of difficulties - there are two; "Too Easy" and "Easy." don't be ashamed at ALL to play on too easy, especially if you're on multiplayer with new people. (up to 4 people - one for each hero)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Here's my elevator pitch for Dungeon of Endless:"It's a rogue-like, tower defense game with Left 4 Dead finales thrown in."And it truly is an amagame of these things. It's like an rogue-like RPG in that you're exploring a randomly-generated dungeon and dealing with the enemies and other things you encounter there.The tower-defense element pulls heavily from real-time strategy and role-playing elements. There's a pretty meaty three-resource system that you engage. You build machines to generate more of the resources then use those resources to build all kinds of offensive and defensive weapons or to level up your heroes (each with their own unqiue attributes, powers and weapons to equip). Every time you open a door in the dungeon your machines produce the goods. There's also a chance of enemy waves spawning -- that's where the tower defense comes in. You need to build defenses to prevent them from running roughshod over your stuff (and eventually destroying your precious energy crystal). Smart, strategic exploration plays a big role here, creating choke points and making sure that enemies don't swarm you all at once is key to survival.Once you find the exit to the dungeon floor there's a final event where you must manually carry your power crystal from the start of the dungeon to the exit -- all the while fending off enemy's. That's where the Left 4 Dead allusion comes into play. These final runs can go horribly if you haven't powered and defended the path. Since I've been playing there's been constant adjustment to the economy and difficulty of the game -- this is the kind of fine tuning you want from a game that's in Alpha. But throughout I've had fun playing the game. Even when the tuning made the game insanely hard. Even when the game is broken Dungeon of Endless is fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: This review is for the final patch prior to the full release of the game. There's currently no Coop mentioned, and I have not tried the ships / gametype variants so I will not mention either.My GOTY candidate. There's a lot more here than what you see at first glance. PROS: - Hero choices make the game varied, and engaging. - Gear and Builds become interesting and somewhat diverse (more on this later).- Resource management is straightforward, and easy to grasp. Interesting decision on how you use your resources added in later patches.- Level of difficulty is very high (this might be a con for some)- Excellent art style.CONS: - RNG can definitely kill your run, hands down. - Balance was lacking a bit. There were some OP builds which made the game easier, though some of these have been addressed in patches.- The game expects you to learn its ins and outs via investing time. It's not very easy to pick up. - Unlocking heroes can be fun, though once you get to the latter heroes to unlock, it feels like a time sink.Overall: Bottom line for me personally is that I really enjoy the depth of the game. It took me hours of fiddling around with what's possible, and strategizing and using tactics and a relatively high level of micromanagement to beat the game on its hardest difficulty. Though RNG can make this game a bit more tedious than I'd like, I stil find this a refreshing take on the genre (or mash of genre's in this case). It's really the gameplay and the extreme level of dedication and understanding of the systems in the game that make this  extremely fullfilling to play. Few experiences have pushed me that close to the edge and I enjoyed every minute of it. There's definitely some downsides, but compared to most triple A releases this game packs a huge punch for the price. It does offer a large amount of replayability in the form of heroes, and playing to their strengths plus adjusting strategy to come up with new playstyles on the fly. You won't win on the first go, and chances are it will take you some time to even clear a few floors. But if you're like me, you'll really enjoy the experience.Once CoOp is added, I'll be back in to spend some time trying to sync with my friends and beat the game for my 7th time.

												Instantly one of my favourite games of all time. I watched this title since it's early release and decided to wait until I could play the finished version. And I wasn't dissapointed.Assembling a team of misfits and taking on a dungeon jam packed with vile monsters and random rewards. Your heart stops momentarily in your chest as a door slides open revealing what could be a life saving bonus or a horde of angry demented beasts that either want to destroy your precious crystal or just tear your heroes to pieces. Character combinations are always worth experimenting with as they can reveal the history of the heoroes and their doomed ship. Aswell as provide perks that will help you push on to the next floor. It's difficult at first, but once you have a firm grasp on how to progress, you will be glued to the screen.I don't just reccomend this game. I demand you play it. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I picked this up in a pack along with Endless Legend and Space because I wanted to get into a new 4x game. This game wasn't on my radar before and I didn't really expect anything from it. However what I found was a surprisingly addictive roguelike that borrowed elements from a dozen other genres put together into a deceptively complex whole. I've only beaten the game once on "easy" (actually the game's hard difficulty) but doing that took nearly a dozen attempts worth of familiarizing myself with the mechanics and each time felt unique and "worth" it.The game's art and music style are very nice and the heroes are interesting, if not in terms of personality at least what they bring to the table in terms of options available to you each run. I feel like they'd work well in a more fully fleshed out RPG setting with expanded mechanics.It would be nice if there was some kind of persistence between tries outside of which heroes you have unlocked to start with as I do feel that is a barrier to replayability currently. However even with that said I feel like this game is more than worth the admission price. One of the most surprisingly enjoyable games I've played recently.

There's a few buyer beware points, however, specifically if you're looking to co-op with friend.The good points:It has very good replayability.Wide enough variety of characters.Multiplayer support.Completely Ironman style saving.Saves migrate completely over steam cloud.The bad point:Sessions for multiplayer can border on four (4!) hours, and there's no save, no lobby controls to limit players, and no private options.I'm not a fanatic about this game but it's a solid rougelike.

												Configure your troops, allocate your dust, build modules, and then open a door.  Sounds simple, but there are greedier and less greedy configurations. content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												PROS-Diverse cast of misfits that you will lead to an inevitable demise.-Creates a wonderfully haunting sense of isolation through both the visual art style and the excellent soundtrack.-Somehow manages to blend tower defence, rts, rpg and roguelike elements together without failing at any of them.-Easy mode will ruthlessly murder your squad over and over again. -Different types of escape pods to unlock, each modifying how the game is played.-Pixellated pugs.NEUTRALS-This is definitely a roguelike, and sometimes you'll do as much as you can and still fail. Sometimes you will find the exit to the next floor in seven or eight rooms, sometimes it will be the last door on the floor. I find that being stretched thin and having to guard three fronts with a handful of turrets and heroes to be half the fun.CONS-An essential tactic for later in the game involves using heores in unpowered rooms in order to prevent enemy spawns. I'm not sure if this is mentioned anywhere in-game. I found out about it on the forums.I can't recommend this strongly enough. If you're a fan of any of the genres listed on the tags, do yourself a favour and pick this up.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Althought I have not yet played Amplitude Studios' branding game, Endless Space, I have played the other two of the series and I can tell that these developers have an extrodinary talent for game design. Talking about Endless Dungeon, it was the first time in a while a game has challenged me in just the right way. Too many times today, games rely on "artificial" difficulty, or difficulty without substance. Not Endless Dungeon. I've played the game many times, and successful runs are scarce. As a fan of both genres the game embodies (a rouguelike dungeon crawler paired with a tower defense), it represents each part of the game in a very solid way, providing an excellent coop strategy game that will certianly last. Just be sure you have a couple hours before you sit down and play it. The only issues that I can name is the inability to save in multiplayer, which I heard will be fixed, and my poor luck to find out about this series and not getting the special heros from pre-ordering other games in the series. These are minor things and barely take away from this fantastic game a whole. Amplitude constantly rolls out new updates, both free and DLC, so there's always a reason to return and play again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												It's an apt testimony to the skill and passion of the Amplitude folks that Dungeon of the Endless has become my go-to timewaster. The premise is simple: Your prison ship's been attacked and you've crash-landed on an uncharted planet. You and your motley band of inmates, ship staff and exotic natives must navigate the twelve floors of the mysterious dungeon you've found yourself in by finding the elevator on each floor and using the "crystal" generator from your escape pod to power it and move to the next level up. That crystal is also needed to power the rooms of the dungeon, providing a variety of resources conducive to your survival, but it is limited by its supply of "dust", and each room left unpowered has a chance to spawn a wave of hostile fauna whenever you open a new door on that floor.The gameplay is an elegant combination of roguelike, tower defence and classic RPG mechanics. It's both accessible and challenging, with a bit less of the luck factor of, say, FTL (you'll rarely be thrown into randomly unsurvivable situations) and more strategic decisions to make rather than a roll of the dice. While plotting your route through the dungeon, protecting the crystal is your primary concern. You'll have a range of modules to install in a dungeon, from resource generators to defensive weaponry, and as your power demand starts to exceed supply you'll have to get clever with which parts of the dungeon you keep powered and where you open new doors. Your heroes' abilities and attributes vary widely. Some are slow but powerful tanks, well-suited to holding a static position; others are technically-minded and can operate or repair the modules you build; others still are nimble speedsters ideal for responding to trouble spots or running the crystal to the elevator. Managing your heroes is therefore crucial to success.The understated soundtrack and the pseudo-pixellated, hand-painted graphics are both surpassingly beautiful, and taken with the game lore (which frequently ties in with that of Amplitude's other titles, Endless Space and Endless Legend) they create a truly unique atmosphere and sense of immersion. The heroes will treat you to some fun banter occasionally, and are great sources of emergent stories. The tale of how you brave robotic swordsman sacrificed himself keeping a horde of nasties from his beloved crystal carrier; or how two of your most dissimilar dungeon explorers form an unstoppable monster-slaying, best-buddy team; are experiences that remain with you long after their runs have ended. Some combinations of characters even have unique backstories of their own, which unfold as they ascend the floors with sometimes-shocking outcomes that I won't spoil here. Simply put, the game oozes personality.Whether you're a fan of the genre, or simply someone who appreciates an old-school challenge or a lovingly-made game, I can't recommend Dungeon of the Endless enough. Keep your eyes on Amplitude, because they've just had an amazing year.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												Rogue-like, ressources gathering, rpg elementa, hero control, micromanagement, tactical combat, tower defense.. arrg thats not even it, lets make this simpler.. You control heroes and progress through a dungeon of your choice, trying to reach the exit.On your way you will build modules to gather ressources to research new tech, level up/heal your hero and build defensive and offensive modules. Even on the easier difficulty the game will get harder and harder as you go. it can become quite addictive. The hero selection allows you to customise and build a team around what you need/prefer and the various 'gamemodes' represnted by the various escape pods, add a few different games options. The game is solid in execution and gameplay. Id think it would end up being too short, but as you go, you will play more carefully and take your time to progress, i ended up playing over 80h (i usualy get bored of most games rather fast). I did not touch the multiplayer yet so i cannot coment on it, but there is also that option.
