content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								For all those Warcraft3 lovers out there, who enjoyed tower and hero defenses just as much as i did:THIS IS YOUR GAME.Once you understood the mechanics of this game (e.g. powered / unpowered rooms or defense / roaming hero) it becomes quite addictive and very tactical.The cool part (compared to wc3 TDs) is that between your turns, you have endless time to improve your heros and roosm itself. PRO:-The variaty of items and champsis not as rich as in wc3 or dota, but added to the concept of tower defense you end up having troubles to decide which tactical way to go and which item/champ comps are suiting you best.-DotE is rarly based on random events (exept for the tech-tree and the item drop). At the beginning it may seem so, but then you havent understood the mechanics yet.  CON:NO MICROMANAGING-You have no control of the Heros, except that you can tell them in which room they should move.-You also have no way of building a maze.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Genius combination of Real-Time Strategy, Tower Defense, RPG-progression mechanics, and Rogue-like elements. Genre mash-ups usually seem chaotic and poorly thought out, but everything in this game works brilliantly. Explore dungeons, fight waves of enemies, manage resources, build defenses, and get to the exit. And if you die... YOU DIE.The alpha still has room for improvement, specifically in terms of controls (a MOBA-style minimap would be nice for managing units in the larger dungeons), but the core gameplay here is pure genius and can be enjoyed by RTS players and Roguelike junkies alike.Post-release review update:TACTICAL MAP FIXED EVERYTHING WRONG WITH THE CONTROLS YES YES YES!Also there's multiplayer and way more heroes now. This is an amazing game! Wurf yo money.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								I love steam, every time I turn it on it shows me something interesting. Today’s interesting find was this, Dungeon of the Endless. It looked and sounded such a curious idea that I had to buy it up. I'm happy I did. The opening cinematic was attention catching and what follows is addictivily fun game play. It's simple to get a hang of the controls but i expect it will take some time to master your own strategies for survival success. The dungeon crawler and tower defence aspects of the game work beautifully together. As you progress through the levels the larger the dungeons get offering more doors to open. More doors open meaning more ways for the monsters to get your heroes and crystal. It took me a few attempts to get past the first floor, carrying a crystal to an elevator is more of a challenge then I thought. Though mad dash's never fail me...shame I lose a hero or two in the process. Anyway I'm enjoying the Alpha greatly and i can't wait to see what more there is to come closer to full release. I highly recommend this game and it deserves all the support it going to get.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												This is how I start off 2015, by staying up ALL night, only to fail on the 10 level.  This game is hard, unexpected and ultimately it is food for the brain.Update #1:   18 hours into the game, straight up addicted, should be doing portfolio work; but this game saps the life from me in all the right places.     "The best video games are the ones that take up too much of your time because you are addicted to them, and they start causing real problems in your life because you borrow time from something else." -Ross ScottWell written dialogue, grade +A pixel art and animation, amazingly interesting Album feature, great characters, addictive gameplay, edge of your seat moments and finally HARD difficulty no matter what difficulty you choose; too easy=mild, easy=hard!Final Verdict: 9/10, should be a 10/10 but there needs to be MORE of everything!!!If you guys are going to make a sequel, give it better pixel art like Mother Russia Bleeds level of detail.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Psycopaths and prison guards thrown into an endless nameless dungeon on a cataclysmic world.  This is the prequel to Endless Space and Endless Legend.  This is the origin story of the Vaulter faction.  This is the best tower defense game ever made.  It's tower defense RPG TBS-RTS.  It's also hilarious.  Amplitude offers free and paid content, I recommend them both.Permanent death mechanics, only save & exit exists.  TF2 characters all present and accounted for.  Multiple modes of play with varying pros and cons, many items to be built with useful and varying functions.  Also, the Grim Reaper shows his face to offer you bargains.  Do you make a deal with death?  Well, it's behind every door, so you might as well!Creative, original, inspired, riveting.  Try it out, or without a doubt, you'll be missing out!

Early Access Review
								The gameplay for this lovely early access title is rather forward; you're goal is to clear the level and escape the dungeon your ship crashed into, and you do this by telling your heros where to go, but they do the actual fighting themselves, you can however give them armor, weapons, and more-or-less create a Super Sentai Force of heros. Its pretty darn amusing when your team consists of a stoic medical robot, a giant, a midget, and a space bounty hunter who seems very similar to another bounty hunter from a Nintendo franchise.This game is without a doubt one of my favorite Early Access games on Steam, and I doubt that willl change.P.S: The ship is my favorite characterP.S.S:Watching your heros fight might sound boring, but it actully requires a fair amount of strategem and smarts.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												Don't let the negative reviews fool you.This game is difficult only because other developers have made their games too easy, holding your hand through most of, if not the entire process.Another company by the name of FromSoftware made a couple of games people should be familiar with... I'm not going to mention them, but they strayed from the "norm" of today. Video games have evolved from simple exciting point grabs, to things where you actually had to put some thought into the experience, back to being needlessly simple point (now known as achievements) grabs.I highly suggest this if you want a game that actually challenges you to use your brain, gives you a proper sense of accomplishment when you complete something, and doesn't hold your hand through the process.I don't suggest this game if you have a difficult time with failure, an issue with perma-death, and an issue with learning a games mechanics on your own.TL;DRGet this game if you want a challenging video game; Don't get this game if you prefer todays interactive storybooks.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Great game, though a little buggy sometimes.  It has a nice mix of turn based resource management, tower defense, squad based real time strategy, and hero development with randomly generated maps and randomly selected enemy types for each level thrown in for good measure.  Some of the heroes do their jobs better than others, but they tend to be unique and fun in their own way.Play Single Player to unlock things and make progress.  Play Multiplayer for silliness and comraderie.

content:

Early Access Review
								I love steam, every time I turn it on it shows me something interesting. Today’s interesting find was this, Dungeon of the Endless. It looked and sounded such a curious idea that I had to buy it up. I'm happy I did. The opening cinematic was attention catching and what follows is addictivily fun game play. It's simple to get a hang of the controls but i expect it will take some time to master your own strategies for survival success. The dungeon crawler and tower defence aspects of the game work beautifully together. As you progress through the levels the larger the dungeons get offering more doors to open. More doors open meaning more ways for the monsters to get your heroes and crystal. It took me a few attempts to get past the first floor, carrying a crystal to an elevator is more of a challenge then I thought. Though mad dash's never fail me...shame I lose a hero or two in the process. Anyway I'm enjoying the Alpha greatly and i can't wait to see what more there is to come closer to full release. I highly recommend this game and it deserves all the support it going to get.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This game is one of my favorites that I discovered this year. Its uniqueness of being a roguelike combined with a tower defense is what drew me to it. Initially I didn't know that was what this game was, becaues the trailer didn't show much of how the gameplay works. The premise is that a ship crashes and you are in control of up to four people who escaped in an escape pod. The escape pod buried itself deep into this planet which you landed on and there are thirteen levels in this "dungeon" which you have to go up. Each level has a certain amount of rooms, and when you open the door to a room enemies may spawn. You also collect Food, Industry, and Science (FIS) each time you open a door. Rooms can have up to 1 slot for a major module like a FIS Creator (one type for each resource), but may also have none. Rooms can also have several minor module slots which can have laser turrets which are the starting minor module. Industry is what is used to build modules and different modules have different Industry costs. Throughout the game you can use science in certain rooms you find to research new modules. There are minor modules that heal your heroes, slow enemies, and much more. However, only powered rooms can have working modules. Rooms are powered by Dust, something that you can collect when you open new rooms and kill enemies. Unpowered rooms that you have opened may spawn enemies each turn, but not every turn.There is a room on every floor that has an exit, and you have to bring the crystal from the first room of the floor to the exit via one of your heroes. This starts a turn and enemies come from every unpowered room. If you successfully get the crystal to the exit, you get onto an elevator and are done with the floor.Heroes are used to attack enemies, increase output from modules, and carry the crystal at the end of the floor. Food can be used to instantly heal them whenever you want, or to level them up and make them more powerful. In some rooms you can find a chest with an item which you can give to one of your heroes, or you can find a merchant which will buy your items or let you buy theirs for FIS or Dust. There are three types of items: weapons, armor, and equipment. They can improve your heroes stats in speed, damage, or defense, or also give them bonuses for fighting with other heroes in a room or alone. There are 16 heroes (now 20 with the latest update) and each one is unique in the type of weapon they use, and the abilities they have. You have control the heroes in your game and can move them to different rooms as you please. They will attack enemies on their own and focus certain enemies over others. I didn't realize this from the trailer but found that it works well instead of having to manually attack enemies. Heroes also unlock active abilities as they level up which you can use for various effects.I've played a ton of this game since I bought it a couple months ago and I love it. The multiplayer is fun, but there are rarely people hosting matches. If you want to play multiplayer then get this game with a few friends. The multiplayer works well and doesn't require any server hosting or anything. For single player the abilitiy to save the game and come back to it later is great, but there is only one save slot. I would highly recommend this game as it is quite cheap for how good it is, especially so on sale! Also it seems that the developers still work on this game, as shown by this latest update today which added new heroes and items. If you enjoy roguelikes, tower defenses, or strategy games, I would highly recommend this game!

												I don't want to sound like I'm exaggerating and I don't want to repeat too much of what everyone else has said... but this game is amazing.I could play this game until I died of starvation. This game is fun. It is relatively casual (except for how addictive it is), it is challenging, it is basically built to be replayed constantly, it is relatively simple yet surprisingly complex, it has multiplayer that doesn't take away from the experience and lets you have fun with friends, the music is what I would consider the upper echelon of music in games.I'm not a homer for this game, I bought it because it was in a bundle with Endless Space and Endless Legend that was reasonably priced and had no real intention of playing it. I knew nothing about it and have 0 stake in giving it a glowing rating but it is honestly just so immensely fun.If you have any interest in roguelikes I cannot recommend this game highly enough.Only complaint - Let players trade items in multiplayer! Sometimes swapping heroes and swapping back works, other times it doesn't.

This game is hard, unexpected and ultimately it is food for the brain.Update #1:   18 hours into the game, straight up addicted, should be doing portfolio work; but this game saps the life from me in all the right places. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Psycopaths and prison guards thrown into an endless nameless dungeon on a cataclysmic world.  This is the prequel to Endless Space and Endless Legend.  This is the origin story of the Vaulter faction.  This is the best tower defense game ever made.  It's tower defense RPG TBS-RTS.  It's also hilarious.  Amplitude offers free and paid content, I recommend them both.Permanent death mechanics, only save & exit exists.  TF2 characters all present and accounted for.  Multiple modes of play with varying pros and cons, many items to be built with useful and varying functions.  Also, the Grim Reaper shows his face to offer you bargains.  Do you make a deal with death?  Well, it's behind every door, so you might as well!Creative, original, inspired, riveting.  Try it out, or without a doubt, you'll be missing out!

content:
Posted: January 22
												The idea behind this game is really nice. Towerdefense, RPG and FTL-like tactics in a neat package. It just doesn't get it strictly right. And it's quite complicate and unintuitive to start with. Loads of info is thrown at the player without warning. The tutorial is a joke, especially for a game of this complexity.Due to the complexity it is even a worse time sink than a lot of rogue-likes. A playthrough takes several hours, my first longer game took 3.5 hours and i "only" made it to the 9th level of 12 or 14 on "very easy". After that the game ramped up the difficulty even more. I encountered a level that went down hard on my♥♥♥♥♥ as door-opening monsters spawned, which freed all other monsters... There was nothing i could do for my crew but heal them until they got overrun.All in all for the price of 4 bucks it's a great game. Just be prepared that it's far more complex and time-consuming than FTL. I'm not sure it really needed that level of complexity. If you're looking for a more casual game, don't even glimpse at "Dungeon of the Endless"!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												I don't remember what exactly prompted me to buy this, but I'm sure it had something to do with the $2.99 pricetag.I was lucky enough to have a couple of friends online that night who had played a couple hours of the game some time before. The 3 of us then spent the next 3 hours playing through one full round (12 levels). It was an absolute blast. I later tried playing by myself, and managed my way through on the second attempt. Even by myself I had fun running around the various floors defending my crystal. It should be noted that this game is infinitely more entertaining and playable with friends (voice chat will be a necessity). Parties of 2 or 4 people are best, but 3 works fine too. The graphics for this game are as they appear in the screenshots; if this artstyle suits you, you'll love the game. If it bothers you, picking another rougelike might be better for you. For me, I like the way it looks, and feel it works well with the genre. It sometimes makes clarity in gameplay a bit muddy, but rarely is it a serious problem. The soundtrack goes hand in hand with the artstyle, and is simplistic and electronic. Thus far I haven't been bored by it, but I'm sure I'll end up replacing the music with my own before too long. I give this game an 8/10. I've had it 3 days and spent a LOT of my free time on it already. I'm not normally a huge fan of rougelikes, but the way it integrates so well with the tower defence, resource management, and RPG elements makes it SUCH a blast. Singleplayer is fun, but multiplayer with friends is infinitely better. Snag it up while it's on sale, and it'll be worth so much more than the $3 that you spent on it.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Questions You May Have About Dungeon of the Endless1. Who put Tower Defense in my Rogue-Like?A. Don't question it it's good for you!2. Why are these monsters so nasty?A. They want your sweet Dust! Or your sweet butt. They may want both. Therefore you must defend yourself with pointy objects, shooty projectiles, and most importantly, TOWER DEFENSE!3. What? How do I Tower Defense?A. Get lots and lots of Industry, a good bit of science for researching stuff... THEN PLOP DOWN ALL THE NEUROSTUNS! ALL THE TEAR GAS! ALL THE PEPPER SPRAY (disclaimer: actually only one pepper spray per room is necessary)! AAAAAHAHAHAHAHAHAAA... Or whatever works for you really. That's what I like though.4. And what about my Squad?A. Explore the sprawling xenobiology research laboratory of the Endless with your ragtag party of guards, prisoners and natives to the world of Auriga! Let your Tower Defense onslaught whiddle down your foes, then have your heroes eliminate the survivors in a few well-placed pokes! Also use some of them to operate resource generators for EVEN MORE RESOURCES which means MORE TOWER DEFENSE!5. Who should I recruit?A. Ignore the naysayers, get Lady Joleri, for she is your tanky Broken Lord savior! Also her Dust deficiency-causing honestly isn't a huge deal. Pretty much everybody can be good too. SO FIND THE RIGHT HERO FOR YOUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUU!6. Should I play the game on Easy or Too Easy?A. EASY IS FOR MANLY MEN! TOO EASY IS FOR MANLY MEN TOO, WHO ARE ALSO MANLY MEN, BUT NOT MANLY ENOUGH FOR NORMAL EASY. BUT DON'T WORRY YOU CAN BE A MANLY MAN (OR LADILY LADY, EQUAL IN POWER, DETERMINATION AND FLEXY SEXY MUSCLES TO ANY MANLY MAN) REGARDLESS OF WHICH DIFFICULTY YOU CHOOSE AND YOU ARE BEAUTIFUL IN YOUR OWN WAY. Just do what feels right.7. I beat the game, am I a cool dude now?A. You were always a cool dude! But keep doing it to unlock more stuck and be THE COOLEST DUDE! 8. Why does the Sanitary Pod give me soap?A. Because don't drop the soap.9. Who's da best?A. You da best.10. Should people buy this game?A. People should buy this game.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Got this just because I thought it was interesting and my friend found it cheap to buy for me. DAMN this is fun! Every door I open just makes me wish it was the exit out of the dungeon as I'm forced to think tactically where I should put my heroes at. Losing even one hero puts me at a huge disadvantage as I rush my heroes from one room in one side of the dungeon to the other to protect my assets and heroes. Can I survive? Or will I die? (Atm, 6th floor, one hero died putting me at a great disadvantage, hopefully will find another replacement, 3 way room crystal with one side without any luck for an exit so I'm technically screwed. XD But it's so fun that the replayability is good!)Hopefully we'll be able to see more content for this game soon!EDIT: So It's finally out and I got to try it after a long time. It's still fun, entertaining, and even the multiplier is quite difficult. XD But nonetheless, very fun. My jurisdiction still stands.

												I don't want to sound like I'm exaggerating and I don't want to repeat too much of what everyone else has said... but this game is amazing.I could play this game until I died of starvation. This game is fun. It is relatively casual (except for how addictive it is), it is challenging, it is basically built to be replayed constantly, it is relatively simple yet surprisingly complex, it has multiplayer that doesn't take away from the experience and lets you have fun with friends, the music is what I would consider the upper echelon of music in games.I'm not a homer for this game, I bought it because it was in a bundle with Endless Space and Endless Legend that was reasonably priced and had no real intention of playing it. I knew nothing about it and have 0 stake in giving it a glowing rating but it is honestly just so immensely fun.If you have any interest in roguelikes I cannot recommend this game highly enough.Only complaint - Let players trade items in multiplayer! Sometimes swapping heroes and swapping back works, other times it doesn't.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Dungeon of the Endless is honestly a game I never thought I'd enjoy. As someone who doesn't care much for pixel art or rogue-likes, I was shocked that this game actually stole my heart. The art is beautiful, the gameplay is fast, tense, and even suspenseful at times. Its humor is top-notch. Even its characters themselves are endearing. And to top it all of, a co-op multiplayer experience that's truly delightful? I couldn't ask for more. If you and your pals are looking for your next big game, I whole heartedly recommend this chance at chaotic bliss.+Pros-Fast paced gameplay. Definitely intense!-Clever take on Tower Defense. -Loyal to the Endless setting. Its even referenced in other Endless titles.-Beautiful aesthetics. Especially the shading and models. No two designs feel bland or too similar.-Rewarding Co-op. It offers so much power to the players.+Cons-Researching is unnecessarily difficult in certain floor generations.-Multiplayer servers occasionally act up and disconnect players. You can't rejoin a lobby either.-The music, while excitingly curious, is somewhat limited. Could benefit from a few more tracks. I've already bought 4 copies for my gang. What's stopping you?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												This game is one of my favorites that I discovered this year. Its uniqueness of being a roguelike combined with a tower defense is what drew me to it. Initially I didn't know that was what this game was, becaues the trailer didn't show much of how the gameplay works. The premise is that a ship crashes and you are in control of up to four people who escaped in an escape pod. The escape pod buried itself deep into this planet which you landed on and there are thirteen levels in this "dungeon" which you have to go up. Each level has a certain amount of rooms, and when you open the door to a room enemies may spawn. You also collect Food, Industry, and Science (FIS) each time you open a door. Rooms can have up to 1 slot for a major module like a FIS Creator (one type for each resource), but may also have none. Rooms can also have several minor module slots which can have laser turrets which are the starting minor module. Industry is what is used to build modules and different modules have different Industry costs. Throughout the game you can use science in certain rooms you find to research new modules. There are minor modules that heal your heroes, slow enemies, and much more. However, only powered rooms can have working modules. Rooms are powered by Dust, something that you can collect when you open new rooms and kill enemies. Unpowered rooms that you have opened may spawn enemies each turn, but not every turn.There is a room on every floor that has an exit, and you have to bring the crystal from the first room of the floor to the exit via one of your heroes. This starts a turn and enemies come from every unpowered room. If you successfully get the crystal to the exit, you get onto an elevator and are done with the floor.Heroes are used to attack enemies, increase output from modules, and carry the crystal at the end of the floor. Food can be used to instantly heal them whenever you want, or to level them up and make them more powerful. In some rooms you can find a chest with an item which you can give to one of your heroes, or you can find a merchant which will buy your items or let you buy theirs for FIS or Dust. There are three types of items: weapons, armor, and equipment. They can improve your heroes stats in speed, damage, or defense, or also give them bonuses for fighting with other heroes in a room or alone. There are 16 heroes (now 20 with the latest update) and each one is unique in the type of weapon they use, and the abilities they have. You have control the heroes in your game and can move them to different rooms as you please. They will attack enemies on their own and focus certain enemies over others. I didn't realize this from the trailer but found that it works well instead of having to manually attack enemies. Heroes also unlock active abilities as they level up which you can use for various effects.I've played a ton of this game since I bought it a couple months ago and I love it. The multiplayer is fun, but there are rarely people hosting matches. If you want to play multiplayer then get this game with a few friends. The multiplayer works well and doesn't require any server hosting or anything. For single player the abilitiy to save the game and come back to it later is great, but there is only one save slot. I would highly recommend this game as it is quite cheap for how good it is, especially so on sale! Also it seems that the developers still work on this game, as shown by this latest update today which added new heroes and items. If you enjoy roguelikes, tower defenses, or strategy games, I would highly recommend this game!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												A neat and fun game that has many unique details in it, and yet it's definitely not flawless! I down voted this game originally thinking that the creators completely failed in their idea, but here I am more than a year later to come back to this game, enjoying it way better than I used to.Still I have to point out these things that are, in my opinion, not right:A playthrough takes way too long for a Rogue-like. It can take 3 to 4 hours to beat it. This makes trying out new chars and tactics a bit tedious. There is still quite a narrow range of strategies to have success in a playthrough.There is no proper tutorial.The multiplayer is a mess.(The gameplay is simply not compatible for multiplayer, you're better off alone)The thing that changed my mind are the free DLC and the welcoming tweaks to the balancing. Random scenarios are more common and more "friendly", so now you actually feel lucky from time to time. A mistake early on can be resolved later (it didn´t used to be like this). But hey, it costs between 12 and 20€ so I can forgive the mentioned cons.So I'm safe to say now that, if you are into these types of games, you'll get entertainment worth your money.

												Basically the video game version of Closing Time by Semisonic-Your goal is to open all the doors up and let yourself out into the world-Its a strategic advantage to turn on all the lights over every boy and every girl-You may not get the option of going home, but you can't stay here-You gather up jackets (prison uniforms and the like)-You move to the exits (with the crystal)-You hope that you've found a friend (because you'll probably die if you don't have a full party)-Every new beginning comes from some other beginning's end (permadeath)-Both are related to alcoholism (trust me on this, just give it some time)The big difference between this game and Closing Time is that in Dungeon of the Endless, the hits keep on coming! (please don't strangle me, just buy the game because it's good)

												Difficult to describe the game. A rogue-like adventure with lots of potential heroes and game-modes to unlock which greatly enhances the game's replayability. Additionally, the resource management and tower-building adds a fun new dimension which makes the game feel very different from other rogue-likes on Steam. (Although keep in mind, this is a rogue-like first, and a tower defense second, if you go in looking for pure tower-defense you might be disappointed.)In any case, I love it when developers who push the boundaries of a genre and succeed in creating something new and wonderful. I highly recommend the game, well worth the price.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've never had so much fun losing at a game. This game combines aspects of the MOBA genre with a genre from the roots of MOBA, tower defense. Maybe I'm overexplaining it. This game is a tower defense game that requires your to manage 3 different resources, a team of heroes, and base construction/map exploration. It allows (and forces you) to build structures to increase your resources and defend your buildings, and a hyper-important power crystal. Resources are throttled tight, forcing the player to be proficient at economy, construction, and hero manipulation. The game features a rogue-like model of character growth and map randomization. This is the first game I've ever played that can be considered primarily rogue-like, and it is a blast. It's really hard, but it's still fulfilling when I get overzealous and open too many doors (Opening another door typically activates a wave of combat. It's a simultaneous unstap step/entering attack phase) in an effort to replenish enough resources to upgrade in time for the first wave.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												This is one of the most complex games of Solitaire ever invented.Play involves "drawing a card"- you "open a room", which may have a number of special properties, including suitability for installing resource generators, getting resources for free, etc.This, in turn, involves drawing further "cards"- whether any monsters spawn from "cards" you have chosen not to "put into your deck" (using Dust to "power them up").  So managing your "deck" is essentially how you play this game; the "heroes", their levels and gear are mere mitigation used to hedge risk.This sounds OK in theory, but in practice, this game is very poorly balanced, and due to severely penalizing modding (it's literally not allowed to set the difficulty upwards if you mod the game), it's never going to be properly balanced by modders and is therefore chock-full of newbie traps, poorly-designed difficulty curves and bad design decisions, like weapons that don't scale well with monsters, random item drops that don't scale, heroes that are basically just statistical trash, shops that frequently don't sell anything you actually want, regardless of cost, a "wit" system that's supposed to boost production but barely gives enough to be worthwhile with practically all of the heroes with the Operate skill (and items that can give it are worthless, since practically none of the non-Operator heroes have enough "wit" to matter), etc., etc., etc.Worst feature?  You literally cannot get rid of party members if you want to trade up, short of suiciding them, with potentially disasterous consequences.  You meet a half-dozen other folks, but you cannot have them join you in any way.  It's a game design decision that makes me shake my head; the choice of whether to stretch one's Food to cover more people, but possibly get stretched too thin and die due to having a weak party, would have enriched the game.  But I suspect that the "4 is the limit" aspect was hard-coded into the UI long before "you'll recruit heroes you find randomly"- it feels like it, anyhow.Basically, this is a messy experimental project where I think the developers lost track of the statistical meaning of their design decisions quite early in the process and, due to their absurd penalty on modding, it's unlikely to ever get polished and fixed by the player community, which is a real shame, because the central idea ("make the world's most complicated Solitaire and make it look like a RTS / Tower Defense game to get gamers to buy it") was very interesting indeed, and in theory, this should be a very good game.  But as it stands, this won't stay on my hard-drive for very long; once I figured out that certain combos of heroes work all right, and realized that runs are essentially pure RNG and involve very little actual skill, beyond managing the "cards" and doing statistical guesswork, and that more than half of the "upgrades" and "defenses" were basically worthless... well, I feel like this was a clever Idea that arrived half-baked, wasn't ever really addressed at a deep level by the developers and can't get fixed by modders, not that it would matter a lot at this late date.  It's too bad, really; this is a game where most of the problems are clearly fixable, but won't ever get fixed.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												"Deleciously retro-looking", is what my wife said to me yesterday, after looking over my shoulder while I was playing Dungeon of the Endless. I just hummed, or nodded my head. I totally agree with her, but I was just too spellbound by this game - especially since the completed version has launched last monday!Don't get me wrong, I could have easily looked over my shoulder and have an indepth discussion about the visuals of the game, because even though this game is a Tower Defense meets Dungeon Crawler meets RPG meets [prolly some other genre] it only has the GOOD elements of each type game. Examples..TowerDef) A wave of monsters only comes after YOU decide to open a door. Don't want to fight for a bit? Just don't touch anything..easyRPG) "Experience" is gathered in a pool and YOU decide who to give that experience too. You can see what kind of effect the added level will have on stats and active or passive abilities. Maybe you want to use that experience on healing or on buying stuff instead? Your choice..What I already found during early access:the visual are delicious,*1the characters are rich, *2the game is versatile and challenging,the play is intuitive,What I realised since the full version:the characters are even richer*2the game is really well-balanced*3*1 Maps are randomly generated each game, you don't always get the same monsters on the same floors, every room looks different with only slight repetitions here and there, every other floor you get a complete new set of rooms and monsters.*2 Regarding rich characters, each character has a short biography, some have interactions with eachother or make random remarks, but you're not drowning in walls of text. Instead you're really drawn to the characters in your team and want to get to know them better. Between more than 10 characters, I've only found 2 that are connected so far..*3 Died at floor 7 out of 12? Stop crying...start again!Buy this futuristic film noirish, action/comedy/attidude-packed, soon-to-be-award-winning-game-(mark-my-words)!

It's a game design decision that makes me shake my head; the choice of whether to stretch one's Food to cover more people, but possibly get stretched too thin and die due to having a weak party, would have enriched the game.  But I suspect that the "4 is the limit" aspect was hard-coded into the UI long before "you'll recruit heroes you find randomly"- it feels like it, anyhow.Basically, this is a messy experimental project where I think the developers lost track of the statistical meaning of their design decisions quite early in the process and, due to their absurd penalty on modding, it's unlikely to ever get polished and fixed by the player community, which is a real shame, because the central idea ("make the world's most complicated Solitaire and make it look like a RTS / Tower Defense game to get gamers to buy it") was very interesting indeed, and in theory, this should be a very good game.  But as it stands, this won't stay on my hard-drive for very long; once I figured out that certain combos of heroes work all right, and realized that runs are essentially pure RNG and involve very little actual skill, beyond managing the "cards" and doing statistical guesswork, and that more than half of the "upgrades" and "defenses" were basically worthless... well, I feel like this was a clever Idea that arrived half-baked, wasn't ever really addressed at a deep level by the developers and can't get fixed by modders, not that it would matter a lot at this late date.  It's too bad, really; this is a game where most of the problems are clearly fixable, but won't ever get fixed.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												I cannot recommend this game highly enough. It's a simple, rogue-like, game that I think is best described as a Dungeon Defense. Your team of up to four heroes are trying to reach the surface of the planet Auriga, which you crashed through after an attack on your spaceship. In order to do that, you will have to navigate 12 (13? I haven't reached the end yet myself) floors of an ancient dungeon left behind by the enigmatic Endless from when they colonized the planet. In addition to collecting more resources needed to continue on your journey, each time you open a door in the dungeon one of several things will happen: monsters will attack from the open room, monsters will spawn in other unlit rooms throughout the dungeon, or a random event (mostly positive, such as finding an item or another hero) will occur. You can't light every room in the dungeon, but you can build defenses in the ones that you do. The monsters will try to attack your dust crystal (an item you NEED to progress through the game), so the game is about lighting paths through the dungeon to funnel the monsters down and wear them down with your defenses. I know I might not have made it sound like it, but this is a surprisingly simple game that is also surprisingly complex and nuanced. Easy to learn, but difficult to master. In later levels the game does start to throw some curveballs your way, such as monsters with erratic behavior and more imfamously those that go after your defenses and not your crystal itself. As I mentioned before the game is rogue-like, so sometimes things do just come down to random chance, but there are plenty of unlockables to be had that don't require beating the game itself, so most always I feel that I gain something on each attempt. Multiplayer is almost none existant, and so the rogue-like elements manage to keep the game feeling fresh and new even after many hours of single player. All things said though, this game is extremely difficult. Harder I think than FTL, I'd say. I know the only two difficulties available are called "Easy" and "Very Easy", but they're anything but; "Very Easy" is more like "Normal" and "Easy" more like "Hard". There are different escape pods that you unlock by beating the game and after reading about them I don't see how they can make the game anything but nightmarishly difficult. Fluff wise, those of you familiar with Endless Space or Endless Legend will find a lot of lore related to the two other games in the franchise, and in fact this game serves as a bridge between the bigger, grander, 4X stratedgy titles that Amplitude is known for. It also takes itself far less seriously, and goes out of its way to make fun of itself in the flavor text. It's my opinion that all the heroes in the game are on a sliding scale of insanity, and the game takes every opportunity to remind you of that.The art work itself, well, look at it. It manages to pull off pixel art as beautifully as Hyperlight Drifter. If anything that I said above sounds appealing to you, than pick up Dungeon of the Endless right away. I can't recommend it enough.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless is a briliant blend of tower defense , roguelike, and squad based rpg. The game handles everything so well that even when you do manage to die you don't really get angry. You just want to get even. As you play you unlock ships and heroes that change the game. Each character is unique and adds variety among how you play the game. I bought this on day one of it's early access and loved it even then. It was just one of those games that was fun even with it's quirks. Watching the game grow as it went through development made it that much more exciting. Amplitude Studios does what they call Game2Gether. Basically buying the games and being active on the forums gives you weight in the polls they put up that changed the course of the games development. It gives the feeling that even as a gamer you matter. The devs really do listen to their fans. This is why they have managed to make three very good, very successful games. Whats more is they all coincide in the same universe. I really can't say much that is bad about the game really. I have become a huge fan of pixel art and this game has some of the best pixel art out there.  The music adds to the feel of the game. Reminds me of Blade Runner actually. Which I am totally okay with. They hit the nail on the head with this game and I hope to see more updates for it whether its content, expansions, dlc... or even a sequel. This game is fantastic...Oh right... They added multiplayer and coop....  Anyone who knows me, also knows I believe coop is the best thing for any game. Look at some of the worst games out there. Add coop to them and they become 10x better simply because you can do it with a friend. We give this game a TheDrastikMeasure.com a 9.5/10  (95)For more reviews, developer interviews, and game previews visit our website. http://www.thedrastikmeasure.com

content:
Posted: June 3, 2015
												Dungeon of the Endless is another entry in Amplitude's loosely connected Endless Universe. The game combines roguelike elements with the dungeon crawler.The premise is this: you are among the handful of survivors remaining after a penal transport ship was attacked. Your escape pod crashes into the bowels of Auriga, a planet that's a wonderous hybrid of fantasy and science fiction, Our heroes must tow their escape pod's energy crystal up to the surface, floor by floor, in order to survive.Players accomplish this trek by opening dungeon doors. This is where the game gets its turn-by-turn basis from, as each door counts for one turn. The turn aspect is central, as the vast majority of your resources will be generated in between turns from various resource modules you'll construct. Of course, opening any given door has a chance of spawning waves of enemies which the player must fend off in an effort to protect the energy crystal. If the energy crystal reaches zero, it's game over.If this sounds like a familiar mechanic, that's because it is. It's the epitome of the tower defense game and you'll find that there is a plethora of offensive, defensive, and supportive modules the player can research and construct to assist in the effort. As in other tower defense games, each of the many enemy types have different priorities and abilities, so strategic use of these modules is important. Simply slamming down the default turret gun isn't going to help you (and in at least one game mode isn't even an option).The goal of each level is to find the exit elevator. When the player finally finds it, they will have to plan for an anxiety-fueled escort mission. One of the heroes must transport the crystal to the exit elevator. Once the crystal is picked up, endless waves of enemies will begin spawning in darkened rooms. To make matters worse, whoever is carrying the crystal will essentially be out of commission for the battle, as bearing the crystal creates a tremendous speed debuff and disables attacks and abilities for that character. Once the crystal makes it to the elevator, the player may leave. Be careful, however, as it is possible to leave without your other party members and they will subsequently be removed from the party.Along with the variety of modules, we have a variety of characters each with different abilities and perks. Each character belongs to one of three factions: crew members, prisoners, or natives. This is a background element but it does affect some perks and stat growth. For example, natives are the cheapest to level up but their stats aren't really impressive in their early levels. In this respect, the game is very much like an RPG, as most characters seem more easily fitted toward one role due to their stat growth and abilities. For instance, characters with a high Speed stat make suitable crystal runners because the effects of the aforementioned debuff will be less noticeable.The graphics use a pixel aesthetic, although it does not feel retro in style. It has a crisp feel to it and is pleasing to the eyes. Despite the simplicity, Amplitude has managed to create an interesting diversity of environments. Indeed, all the rooms are invariably boxy, but it's clear they put some work into trying to make the floors feel different. There's an actual sense of progress across geographic space by using different artistic themes for the decor.The sound quality is excellent. However, while the soundtrack is fantastic you may find it a bit repetitive after a few hours of play. I found myself turning the music off and turning on other sources for background noise after some time.Finally, the way in which this game unravels its lore is extremely subtle and I love it. Small vignettes explaining unseen stories can occur between levels, but only if you have the appropriate characters in your party. These stories can be simply amusing, explain what a character is all about, or inform on the relationships between our starring cast. The coolest thing about these is that each story ends in a buff being granted to those involved, empowering you for the floors ahead.Overall, I recommend this game enthusiastically. It's a wonderful blend of many different game mechanics that somehow seems to work. However, one final warning to any potential buyers: this game is difficult at first. Do not be fooled by the two options of Easy and Too Easy. I recommend chewing on Too Easy at first until you get the hang of the game. Some events are high risk/high reward and the choice of whether to take that risk is best served by a judgment cultivated in the crucible of Dungeon of the Endless.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2016
												Dungeon of The Endless: Oh, Snap!If you’ve been following my progress through reviewing my Steam library, you know that I have a soft spot for Amplitude’s games. They can be pretty technical, and even convoluted at times; but they’re damn good. And I have finally spent some time with their Rogue-Like game, Dungeon of the Endless, and I have to say, it’s really good.IDungeon of the Endless differentiates itself by being both a Rogue-Like dungeon crawl, and a tower defense. Which, I mean, if you pitched that to me I would probably have told you it was a bad idea.But they make it work. Well.What makes the game good? Amplitude has a history of making their games really mechanically dense-- In a somewhat off putting way. It takes time to become accustomed to the systems in their games. Dungeon of the Endless has a very good balance. It has depth without being opaque. There is definitely a bit of a learning curve, but it won’t take you fifty hours to become comfortable with it.The conceit behind the dungeon crawl being that you crash land on Auriga in an escape pod, and have to fight your way through the different floors of the Endless facility your pod bore through. The Endless being a precursor race, not unlike the Forerunners from Halo. You start out with two heroes, from an opening selection of four. Each hero has a unique feel, some being slow, tanky, and ranged. While others are fast, melee glass cannons. And they all have unique abilities that can significantly alter the flow of combat.One such ability makes all of the enemies in a room fight each other, rather than your dudes.Each hero is suited to particular tasks, and DotE requires you to learn their strengths and exploit them. Once you get a feel for it, it really comes together. I was having issues getting further than the the halfway point in the dungeon, and just reading a few tips on the mechanics vastly improved my success with the game. One of the more interesting mechanics present in DotE is that while the game is turn based, it’s not turn based in the traditional sense. And it doesn’t take the MMO/Bioware route either. The game has pausable real-time combat, but turns are initiated by opening the various doors present in the dungeon. Once you open a door, a ‘turn’ is counted and you either have to engage in real-time combat-- or you are given some kind of reward for exploring.Opening doors is how time is progressed; I.E. cooldowns on abilities are measured in doors. And each opened door accrues more resources. … Yeah the game has resources.Like the other games in the Endless universe, they operate with a system of resources known as Food, Industry, Dust, and Science. AKA. FIDS. DotE is no exception. You have a base income in each resource so you will always be generating something, but in most cases you need to build ‘modules’ to generate more on a per turn bases. This is where the Tower Defense aspects come in, as well as the strategy. Would you rather have a lot of upgraded defense modules? Then you’ll need Science and Industry. Would you rather have a higher level Heroes, and a bunch of lower level modules? Food and Industry. And so on.Industry builds the modules. Science improves them. Food heals Heroes, and increases their levels; it can also allow you to recruit other heroes you meet in the field. And finally Dust, which might be the most important of them all.Dust allows you to power the individual rooms that make up the floors. And while it isn’t necessary to power each and every room, there are significant incentives to get as much dust as possible per floor.Every unlit room has a chance to spawn enemies. More enemies means more chances for them to reach your Crystal. (It’s a power source, think the Ancient in DOTA.) That’s a bad thing. Also every time it’s attacked, you lose Dust. This is a worse thing. You can stop this by having a hero stand in a room, or by powering it with Dust. Each room takes ten Dust to power. Now the floors in this game are big and sprawling. You will almost never be able to power each room, and this is where you have to plan ahead. Making kill rooms, choke points, and other sorts of stockades against the enemies DotE throws at you.It’s a fine balancing act between having enough resources to defend yourself, improve your party, and exploring. One mistake will hardly derail your run, but it can put you in a significantly worse position that becomes harder and harder to crawl back from.Most deaths in this game are slow and painful.Each door opened is a risk reward proposition. As the game continues on, and the amounts of Dust you receive become less and less you have to really judge which doors to open, and when to open them. Sometimes a single floor can take upwards of twenty minutes, because you want to be very systematic with your exploration.On each floor, as you progress and open up more rooms eventually you’ll find the elevator. This is the exit to the next floor up. Now, this game wouldn’t be a Rogue-Like if it didn’t hate you, right? So in order to progress to the next level it requires you to take the Crystal, and walk it to the exit. Easy right? Nah. It makes each unlit room continuously spawn waves of enemies that are, you guessed it, attracted to the Crystal. You have to protect your heroes and make it to the exit to progress. And it can be pretty nerve wracking.But it’s also very satisfying to get into the elevator and slam the doors shut on the horde of monsters trying to devour you.And this is probably my favorite part of DotE. Between each level, your characters have little snippets of dialogue that really build their character. Like, I didn’t think there was much to the individual characters... Until I recruited Sara Numas into a party with Gork “Butcher” Koroser.At first they didn’t really interact. Until eventually she recognized him. And started asking him about his past. Eventually she broached the subject of a world that he fought on. And, from the way she spoke, it sounded like he was doing more murdering than anything else… Turns out Gork was responsible for murdering Sara’s parents. She, obviously, wasn’t very happy with him. Gork, being the kind of guy to take pleasure from murder, laughed in her face about it. Sara then proceeded to tell him she would kill him after they got out of the Dungeon… Well Gork kept picking at Sara. Pushing her buttons… Eventually she snapped and attacked him.And Gork killed her.Not only was I blown away at the hidden interactions between the different characters, and the implication that there could be many more of these, but also that my best hero was just killed and there wasn’t a damn thing I could do about it.In that moment I was shocked, angry, and completely impressed. To quote a modern sage, “I’m not even mad, that’s amazing.” This single moment defined how I feel about Dungeon of the Endless. I never really know what it’s going to throw at me, and it keeps surprising me. I didn’t expect this game to be as good as it is. I didn’t expect it to be as approachable as it is. And I damn sure didn’t expect the sound track to be so good.The music is almost maliciously relaxing.This game is really good, and I’ve started gushing.Check out Dungeon of the Endless, it’s worth the price of admission. I was hesitant to pick it up, and got it on sale; I have no regrets. Did I mention it has multiplayer?If you liked this review, check out 100HourSave.com

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												After you've hurtled through space and crash landed your ship on the surface of a strange planet, you will pick two survivors to make your journey to the escape pod with. Each character has different statistics, strengths, weaknesses and abilities. There are a certain number of rooms per floor, and once you have discovered the escape route, you'll progress to the next floor. Sounds easy enough, right?Wrong. Apart from the room you start off in, you have a small number of resources (Dust) and you need to power the Crystal. Why? Monsters, obviously. If you don't power the crystal, you can't light the rooms through the floor as you go. rooms that aren't lit will act as a spawn point for monsters, and then they'll come and destroy your crystalhead straight for your Crystal to destroy it.Each time you open a new room you have a chance to obtain some dust allowing you to power other rooms. You might also get lucky and find self-powered rooms. These are great however you can't unpower the room and reclaim dust from it to use on another room. This makes your management of dust important, it also makes you think about which route you're going to take and forces you to plan ahead.Once you've discovered the exit, you can retrieve the crystal from the starting room and make your way to the exit. On your way to the exit you will have to fight through waves of enemies which will constantly spawn in the unlit rooms until you leave the floor.One thing to be aware of is that if your character dies then thats it, they stay dead, they don't just respawn on the next floor. All is not lost though as you can recruit other characters you come across to replace them. If you come across a character you haven't unlocked yet and recruit them you will unlock them but only if you keep them alive for 3 floors. This gives the game a lot of replay value if you're like me and wanted to unlock every character.There is a certain degree of autonomy in Dungeon of the Endless. Turrets and characters will automatically attack any enemies in the same room as them, leaving you to just strategically place them along the monster's path. You don't have to sit and micro manage each of your party members or turrets.The game also features research which allows you to get upgrades for your defences.What i like about this game is that it makes you think, you can't just rush through each level unless you want to do so with major risk of death. The game makes great use of some beautiful pixel art and the variance between floors/ships is a nice touch. Funnily enough one of my favourite features is the games soundtrack which just fits in perfectly, each level brings its own sound. Even after putting 30+ hours into the game i still have fun with it whenever i jump back into it, for the money it's a gem of a game.

Early Access Review
								I havent expected much from this game and it exeeded all my expectations. Classic turn of all rouge like/lite games was replaced with opening a door. Every time you open any door you receive access to next room. Room can contain different bonuses or monsters. You need DUST to power new rooms. But you have never enough of it to power all rooms at once and every unpowered room can spawn squad of monsters every time you open the door. The more unpowered rooms you have the more monsters can come. So you need to (despite of random nature of labyrinth) plan your advance and do whatever it takes to not allow monsters to owerwhelm you. Once you have found an exit from dungeon you need to transport your power crystal towards it. When you start to moove your crystal rooms start to loose power and monsters start to spawn with extreme rate. So once you have started mooving crystal - time working against you so you need to escape the level as soon as you can.Main disadvantage - multiplayer is not ready yet.Main Advantage - haven't encountered any bugs yet. No bugs at all.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												As someone who usually absolutely despises roguelikes, I have to hand it to these devs. This is a roguelike that is actually pretty good! So many roguelikes just create "difficulty" with brute force randomness, but this game actually has a lot more strategy and a lot more interesting decisions to make. I especially like how the light switch mechanic works to shift the monster spawning around, and the fact that you can switch it up on the fly. Sort of reminds me of Desktop Dungeons where exploration itself is a resource. Similar principle at work here, which is very interesting. Even though escort missions tend to be an infamous no-no in most games, it actually serves a fun and interesting purpose here.Ultimately, though, I still don't think this game is for me, so I won't be playing it any further, personally. Because as much as there is a TON of stuff in here that I like, it still has those classic roguelike annoyances, such as opening a door and getting insta-ganked because randomness. Don't get me wrong, some people LOVE that, but it is one of the main reasons why this player specifically does not care for roguelikes.Tower Defense? Yes.RTS elements? Yes.Turn-based strategy? Yes.Squad-based tactics? Yes.Resource management? Yes.Survival? Yes.Roguelike randomness + permadeath? No thanks.But even as a person who has no taste for most games in the roguelike genre, I have to say that this game is really really interesting and worth checking out. Even though it's not for me, I can tell it's something special.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Alright, I really need to re-edit this. Before I start, I DO recommend this game, because you WILL have fun. A ton of fun. The game's great. Incredibly unique, fun, interactive, fun characters, fun concepts, etc etc. That being said, some elements of the game can be really, really frustrating if you're unlucky. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- RNG is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. It really is. Just to put some perspective, I just did a Drill run aiming to unlock the next pod (requires beating 24 floors), and because of *1* single bad batch of RNG, I lost. No counterplay, nothing I could do, I just got a bad batch of enemies and was forced to lose after 2 hours of intensive playing. My characters had a great skill spread (Pyro / others for AOE work), were highly leveled, all of my modules were highly leveled and had a great mix of them, but nope, one unlucky batch of enemies and it was impossible to win. Keep in mind that I had absolutely NO difficulty WHATSOEVER with the first 20 floors. None. Just 1 bad RNG batch, forced to lose. Cool. - Enemies are way too difficult to differentiate. After 30 hours I still struggle to tell which does what, and to my knowledge there's no way of knowing. There should be a monster encyclopedia that shows you and tells you their abilities. Speaking of which, explosive enemies feel hugely unbalanced. In a game where the spawns consist of a set few enemies per floor, if you get explosive enemies and some crappy RNG, you can get a huge wave of them and have them all explode at the same time trying to kill your modules, which actually just 1-shots your whole team and insta-kills any low HP characters you have. Almost no counterplay to this. You just bank mid-fight on killing them ASAP or at least negating as much damage as you can. - The UI is messy. For around the first 20 hours I actually didn't delve in to turret upgrades because I struggled to actually differenciate what the turrets did and how effective they actually were. Hell, the creators of the game thought it was even appropriate to slap jokes and puns in to the actual descriptions of these turrets which made learning what they do even more annoying instead of just having a box that pops up with a joke if you hover your mouse over the icon. - Items feel really, really lame. Anyone who plays the game can definitely agree with me on this. Some of the items are great and come with skill upgrades, and some of the items feel really good when you get them, but there are so many items that feel like filler items. They have almost identical stats to other items, but they'll just be strictly worse by "2 less attack" or something like that. It's not a matter of "It's a starter item, so it'll be worse" because the rarity of the items are the same. There's literally just one item that does the same thing as another, but better. - The "Easy" and "Too Easy" terminology is really off-putting for new players. The game's really difficult, so clearly the devs were trying to be funny with those labels. In reality, easy is actually like hard, and too easy is like normal. There aren't any other difficulties. There are pods that you can choose from, and certain pods have effects that can make the game harder (which is like "Insane" difficulty in most games). New players are left wondering why the game is unbeatably difficult for them when they're only in "EASY'. I can only imagine a bunch of people gave up or refunded when seeing that "EASY' was way, way too hard for them. You're practically required to start off a bunch of runs in "Too Easy" to figure out the game for the first 10 hours. - The game only has 1 song. Yup, 1 song (2, but the other is only briefly when you carry the crystal). It's basically a 15 second loop over, and over, and over, and over. Fortunately it's not an unpleasant.. "song", so this isn't all that annoying and you don't exactly notice in game. But really, they couldn't come up with some awesome 8-bit soundtrack? Would've been so good for this game if it felt more arcade styled. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Overall the game is fantastic, but there are some definitive issues that make it feel REALLY frustrating to play instead of a relaxing arcade-like experience. You get some good, clean runs, and you have a blast, but then you get 1 bad RNG experience and it completely puts you off from replaying. There's a lot here they should fix.

												Best Rogue-Like other than Binding of Isaac: Afterbirth. Buy this if you don't have BoI:A. Now.Previously I left this review at those few sentences, but I must go on.This game is in my top 5 Rogue Likes, as it features interesting gameplay that forces you to evaluate risk/reward in every step you take. The game is divided up so whenever you enter a door, it is like ending a turn, meaning it is split up nicely and gives you a second to breathe, a calm before the storm if you will, and then immediately gives a 30 second push of hardship.All of this combined with beautiful graphics and a fantastic difficulty balance and character pool makes this a wonderful game that I would certainly recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												This is not an easy game. You'll be confused, lost, sad, and alone at the beginning. However, as you progress through the game, you learn that life isn't so terrible, and that there may be a chance. Then you die and have to start over. Everything is different now; the randomized maps make predicting what your up against impossible. One thing is still the same though: you learned a little bit about how this game works now. You go through and get a bit farther, then die. Repeat. Repeat. Repeat. Eventually, you find out that there is a backstory if you are so inclined, otherwise you can continue to treat it like an evil arcade machine. This game has a lot of surprises in it that really make me happy: quite a bit of work was put into it and the fact that the creators cared is evident throughout.I would definitely recommend this game to anybody that likes being challenged and having to figure things out the hard way on their own. There is nothing quite so satisfying as making it past a level that maybe you shouldn't have, or trumping the unstoppable forces with sheer cunning. Very entertaining, fun and easy to pick up and burn a few minutes or a few hours of your free time! Would recommend out of 17.

												I stay up too late because I want to finish my run.  I wake up early because I want to start another.  I have not been gripped like this by a single player game in a very long time.  This game is extremely fun and addictive.  There is a wonderful balance of simplicity and complexity, and there is so much variety on how you can play the game.  If you enjoy tower defense games you will LOVE this.  You don't have to build towers even, you can beat the game with just your heroes.9/10, excellent game. If characters had conversations between every single floor this game would be a 10 for me.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I'm thoroughly enjoying this game already.  I am only a few hours in, but am having a ball.  I am an old man, and remember when Rogue was the new thing (hell, I remember when Pong was the the new thing) and this brings back those fond memories.  It isn't the big graphics hog that I am used to these days with the Mass Effects and Fallouts, but has a great old school vibe that gives it a great flavor.  Gameplay is a combo of dungeon crawl and tower defense, and is accomplished very successfully.  The humor is a nice touch, and is funny without being too cheesy.  (The description of the Energy Bar really made me chuckle.)I grabbed it on sale, and call it a great bargain.  If you're looking at it outside of sale season, I think you'll still get your money's worth.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I am a big fan of this game.  I originally got it before official released and loved it then, and love it even more now.The only way I can explain this game is it is almost like a very fast pace 4x game.  You explore the dungeon, finding rooms, loot, and other charactersYou expand by claiming rooms as your own using dust to power them.  (And surprising choices on what you claim and don't claim can change you from winning to utter defeat)You exploit by taking a whole wing of the dungeon and build up all your building there and stockpiling resources for the next floor.You exterminate, because if you aren't opening every door and killing everything that moves, you will not be leveled, you won't have tech and you won't have resources to make it through.Another thing I love about this game is you will never stop being surprised.  I am 60 hours of game play in, I just had a combination of characters in my team that caused a major event to happen between floors to the point I am standing up walking around the room like, crap, crap, crap, now what am I going to do.  This never happened before, why why did this happen to be 2 floors before the end aaahhhhh....  Pro:-Quick action   You can load up and play through a floor in 10 minutes, or play through a game in under 2 hours (If you live 2 hours :) )-RPG Elements   Your characters don't really get experience, but you can level them with food.  There are a lot of characters each with unique skill sets that are all kinda fun.  If you are like me, you even end up having teams you like.  Ultimately, the only thing you must have in you party is a fast hero, and there are plenty of them.-Building Elements    You might have to unlock them all, but there are choices for every play style.  -Replay Value    Even with just the variate of characters the game has massive replay.  Then, they added different pods before release which add a whole new level to the game by changing the core rules.  Cons:-Difficult     It is just unforgiving.  One mistake and your game can just be done.  Two mistakes and you are a better man then me if you survive.  (Many people will call this a pro)-Monster and item variety     There just isn't a lot of options for monsters and loot.  You get better version of the same gear and there is some variety in monsters, but I feel it is a bit lacking.-Cost     How can this company stay in business and make me more totally awesome games if they only charge $12.  They should raise it to $30 ;)

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												A great rogue-like dungeon crawler. It's one of those games that requires you a few tries to finally get it. You'll likely die on the very first floor on your first attempt, but as you play again and again, you start to witness how much strategy and team micro-management is actually required to succeed.The premise of the game is as follows: There are 12 floors in the dungeon. After every 2 floors you're in a new type of zone with new types of enemies, each time getting harder and harder. There's a wide choice of heroes to pick, though most are locked at the start. You can pick any 2 to begin with, and over the course of dungeon crawling you'll be randomly coming across others and able to recruit them to make up a team of 4.Now here's where you have to get tactical. You have a crystal that is your power source, which you must protect at all costs, and as you make progress through the dungeons, you find Dust, which is used to power up the rooms. Rooms where you've restored power allow you to build researched modules that generate resources for you or act as buffs, whereas rooms without power are dangerous and can randomly spawn mobs every time you open a door anywhere on that floor. The goal is to find an elevator on your current floor and to bring your crystal power source there.So the game involves a lot of planning, strategy, tactics, and team management, as well as a bit of luck. As with most rogue-like games, if you lose at any time (team gets wiped out or crystal gets destroyed), you have to start over from the very beginning again. Losing in this game can feel rather demoralising if you've gotten far, since a single dungeon run could take a few hours rather than half an hour that many other rogue-likes have.A bit of trial and error is required to grasp the mechanics of the game and learning from one's mistakes, particularly where hero combinations are concerned, as some can result in unexpected cutscenes in between levels where one of the party members gets killed off by another.The gameplay is really addicting if you like tactics and turn-based mechanics, but as I mentioned, it is hard, so be warned. There are two difficulty levels - 'Too Easy' and 'Easy', but they're more like 'Normal' and 'Hard', so don't be fooled by the wording. If you don't mind the challenge, then this game is definitely worth getting. You can play it both solo or multiplayer co-op.

												As I grow old, the number of games I enjoy seems to be decreasing but this game is a nice surprise.You can take your time to plan between turns (opening doors), and the action part is refreshing as you can actively choose which area the monster will spawn (by powering rooms).The graphics is excellent and the game even played on my old notebook, a core i7 with intel hd 3000.I recommend it for everyone who likes roguelikes, it's different but in a good way.

As with most rogue-like games, if you lose at any time (team gets wiped out or crystal gets destroyed), you have to start over from the very beginning again. Losing in this game can feel rather demoralising if you've gotten far, since a single dungeon run could take a few hours rather than half an hour that many other rogue-likes have.A bit of trial and error is required to grasp the mechanics of the game and learning from one's mistakes, particularly where hero combinations are concerned, as some can result in unexpected cutscenes in between levels where one of the party members gets killed off by another.The gameplay is really addicting if you like tactics and turn-based mechanics, but as I mentioned, it is hard, so be warned. There are two difficulty levels - 'Too Easy' and 'Easy', but they're more like 'Normal' and 'Hard', so don't be fooled by the wording. If you don't mind the challenge, then this game is definitely worth getting. You can play it both solo or multiplayer co-op.

content:
Posted: January 21
												The gameplay itself is fine, but...The game is a huge tedious time sink, one session takes 3+ hours.The multiplayer totally ruined whatever positive thoughts I had for the game. The network code was clearly done by someone with no experience. It takes multiple tries to get a game going, and if someone leaves mid-game, the state gets corrupted beyond repair. The game makes autosaves, but when you try to load and regroup, players will most likely fail to reconnect. The timeouts are ridiculous, 5-15 minutes of looking at the loading screen while the game just waits. And finally, even if you do manage to get it to work, a successful run requires intense cooperation and communication, and there are very few decent human beings playing this. It takes just one person to ruin the game for everyone.
